name: Martinez Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This strong but balanced cocktail calls for a gin with fresh floral aromatics along, and light sweetness to balance the vermouth. Sunset Hill's blend of cucumber, juniper, and rose make it an excellent choice for the Martinez.
instructions:
Shake up thoroughly, and strain into a large cocktail glass. Put a
quarter of a slice of lemon in the glass and serve. If the guest prefers
it very sweet, add two dashes of gum syrup.
notes: The Martinez is a tricky cocktail to pin down. Even in its earliest mention in 1884, the author provides not one, but two different recipes for this tasty tipple. Although many people consider it to be the missing evolutionary link between the Manhattan and the Martini, lots of people don't even know it exists. So what keeps the Martinez going? A lot actually. First of all, the Martinez is actually the predecessor to the Martini, which is widely considered the greatest cocktail ever to be poured. The Martinez plays to a much older style though. Where the Martini is dry and crisp, the Martinez is lush and round with rich spice notes to balance everything out. Like many truly classic cocktails, everyone likes to drink their Martinez a specific way, so feel free to play around until you find yours.

name: Traditional Martini (Sweet)
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.
notes:
From this we can see that the Martini, containing just gin, sweet
vermouth, and bitters, was really a gin version of the Manhattan. And like the Manhattan, when ordered normally it would be made with sweet
vermouth, and when ordered "dry" with dry (French) vermouth.

name: Traditional Martini (Dry)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: It's hand crafted, and small batch quality, paired with its bright citrus flavor and rich botanical aromatics make Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin an excellent choice for the ultimate gin classic; the Martini.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.
notes:
From this we can see that the Martini, containing just gin, sweet
vermouth, and bitters, was really a gin version of the Manhattan. And like
the Manhattan, when ordered normally it would be made with sweet
vermouth, and when ordered "dry" with dry (French) vermouth.

name: Margarita
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Monte Alban Silver is an excellent choice of tequila in a margarita, as its fruity, floral aromas pair perfectly with the bright citrus. Its creamy finish gives this sour cocktail balance and body.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lime and salt. Shake remaining
ingredients with ice and strain into glass.
notes: The origins of the Margarita are positively shrouded in mystery. The stories laying claim to its creation are as numerous and as colorful as the spectrum of Margarita variations floating around bars today. In many of those stories the drink is named after a woman. In 1945, Jose Cuervo, began running an ad campaign with the slogan, “Margarita: It's more than just a girl's name.” The campaign was a huge success, and the Margarita went on to become one of America's favorite cocktails. The Margarita is a derivative of a family of drinks called Daisies, and in one story, a bartender creates the Margarita accidentally by mistakenly grabbing a bottle of tequila while preparing a Brandy Daisy. According to legend, the customer was delighted with the result, and spread the news far and wide. The bartender decided to call his drink a “Margarita” which is Spanish for “Daisy”.

name: Daiquiri
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The daiquiri is one of the original "sour' cocktails, which is a combination of spirit, sugar, and juice. Because there are so few ingredients, quality and balance are key. Calypso white rum has a light, sweet sugar can flavor, that supports the other ingredients, and balances nicely to create a simply delicious classic.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Cuba holds a special place in history for many reasons—among them, the Daiquiri. In the small town of Daïquiri in 1898, Jennings Stockton Cox, an American engineer, led one of the earliest efforts to exploit Cuba's iron-ore mines. As recompense for leaving his secure position in the US, Cox was given generous wages and a ration of Bacardí Carta Blanca. According to legend, Cox was running low on gin one evening while entertaining guests, so he mixed up a punch with limes, sugar, and rum. Cox and his team took to drinking this new concoction and dubbed it the Daiquiri in honor of the city where they lived. The recipe eventually made its way back to the States and became a mainstay for cocktail bars. Bartender's note: for a truly authentic Daiquiri, use Bacardí Superior, which is made using the same recipe and yeast strain as Bacardí Carta Blanca.

name: Sidecar
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Meukow's rich aromas of baked spices and fruit combined with its round medium body are the perfect pairing for the classic Sidecar. It's dry-yet fruity flavor bond with the sweet citrus to create a deliciously balanced cocktail with a warm spicy finish.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Supposedly the Sidecar originated at the Ritz Hotel in Paris sometime in the early 20th century. Recipes began appearing in multiple publications in the year 1922. Widely considered to be one of the best cocktails of all time, the Sidecar is a very delicate balance of sweet and sour against the earthy backdrop that brandy provides. Recently, some bartenders have even begun making Bourbon Sidecars by substituting bourbon for the brandy. There are generally two different schools of thought when it comes to proportions in the Sidecar. The French school leans toward all three parts in equal amounts, while the English school calls for twice the amount of brandy. Both are fine, but the former tends to hide a lot of the brandy's flavor nuances. Therefore, we'll stick with the Brits on this one.

name: Mai-Tai (Trader Vic Version)
instructions:
Shake ingredients without ice. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned
glass. Garnish with lime shell, mint, and skewered pineapple and
cherry.
notes: The Mai-Tai is a bit of a drama queen, to be honest. The first one was created in 1933 by Don the Beachcomber at his restaurant in Hollywood. Eleven years later Victor J. Bergeron created a different drink by the same name at his eponymous California restaurant, Trader Vic's. For the sake of time, we'll spare you all the details. Just know that both men claimed to have created this cocktail. According to legend, the first person to taste Trader Vic's version cried out “Maita'i roa ae!” which translates roughly to “Out of this world! The best!” or something along those lines. Don't worry though, you don't need to speak Tahitian to enjoy it. The Mai-Tai has been butchered over the years, and many bars will serve you something neon with an umbrella if you order one. A true Mai-Tai is rich, amber, and rum-heavy—tiki style at its finest.

name: Brandy Cobbler
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy's smooth buttery aroma along with flavors of rich fruits make it a great choice for the classic brandy cobbler. Notes of orange peel, apricots and vanilla are accentuated by the tart alcohol that leaves a crisp balanced finish to this classic cocktail.
instructions:
Combine brandy, syrup, and soda water in red-wine glass. Fill glass
with shaved ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve with straws.
notes: According to Jerry Thomas circa 1862, a cobbler—a class of drink all its own—is a simply a spirit or wine sweetened with sugar and fresh fruit, and served over ice. Most early versions used wine as a base spirit, but eventually cobblers of all different sorts began cropping up in American bars. Dale DeGroff is generally credited with standardizing the additional step of muddling the fruits and spirits, making for an exceptionally fresh-tasting drink. These cocktails are fairly flexible as far as ingredients go, so always opt for something seasonal. The Fruit is largely responsible for the flavor here, so the riper, the better. Mr. Thomas actually calls for a whopping four ounces in base spirit in his cobbler recipe, but most people knock it down an ounce or two if only for the pleasure of enjoying more than one.

It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Brandy Crusta
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Hartley Brandy's rich buttery aroma along with notes of orange peel and apricot, make it a excellent choice for the Brandy Crusta. It's sweet fruit flavors enhance the fruit  while it's crisp balanced finish cuts the tart lemon producing a balanced cocktail.

Instead of Angostura bitters, consider New Orleans' own Peychaud’s Bitters - a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Curl the zest spiral
on its side in glass. Stir ingredients with ice and strain into glass.
Garnish with orange.
notes: There's a good chance you've never seen or heard of a Brandy Crusta, which is an unfortunate result of the circle of life of cocktails. The Crusta is actually the precursor to many a cocktail, including the Sidecar, the Cosmopolitan, and even the Margarita in a sense, but there is a noticeable difference at play in these recipes—proportions. The Brandy Crusta is essentially a healthy dose of brandy seasoned with mere dashes of other flavoring ingredients. This style of drink allows the drinker to really appreciate the base spirit without being overwhelmed by its potency. Perhaps the most impressive part of this cocktail is its lemon-shell garnish. Getting it right can take a bit of effort, but it's worth the trouble. If you're having trouble getting it to stay in place, try frosting the rim of the glass and the lemon peel and then letting them sit until a hard crust is formed.

name: Brandy Daisy
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: It's smooth fruit flavor and buttery aromatics enhance the rich raspberry notes of the Brandy Daisy, while its crisp balanced finish cuts the tart lemon, producing a sweet balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into beer mug or 8-oz. metal cup. Add ice.
Garnish with fruit.
notes: The Daisy is another one of those categories of drinks that have fallen out of the general public's pool of knowledge over the last century or so. Like cobblers, flips, and other classes of drinks, the Daisy itself is fairly flexible when it comes to ingredients. One of the earliest recorded Daisy recipes is Jerry Thomas's Brandy Daisy, dating back to 1862. Unlike most standard recipes at the time, his called for Curaçao and a few drops of Jamaican rum, one of Brandy's closest spirit companions. Most other classic recipes tend to favor grenadine or raspberry syrup over Curaçao and omit the rum. In our version, raspberry marries beautifully with lemon, making this cocktail the perfect drink to sip on a sunny afternoon on the porch.

name: Champs Elysees Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Meukow's rich aromas of spice and fruit combined with its round medium body are the perfect pairing for the elegantly herbal Champs Elysees. It's dry-yet fruity flavor bond with the sweet citrus to create a deliciously balanced cocktail with a warm herbaceous finish.

Also consider world-famous Peychaud’s Bitters in this cocktail. A proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices with a flavor profile that is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: No one does elegance quite like the French, and this cocktail is no exception. You've likely heard of the Champs Elysées in Paris, the long, illustrious avenue stretching all the way from the Louvre to the Arc de Triomphe and on to the Défense at the western edge of the city. The name, which is an allusion to Greek mythology, translates to Elysian Fields. This was the place where righteous souls were believed to go after death to continue living blessed and happy lives, and hopefully drinking these. This heavenly concoction seems to have first appeared the Harry Craddock's 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book, though little else is known about it's history. The Champs Elysées is earthy and distinctly aromatic without being overly herbaceous, and it makes an exquisite after-dinner drink. All things considered, this cocktail is très très chic.

name: Jack Rose Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The Jack Rose is a history lesson in itself—a veritable “blast from the past”, if you will. This drink was originally made with applejack, a uniquely North American high-proof brandy, which was essentially made by distilling apple cider. As applejack has gone down in popularity, the Jack Rose has become an increasingly rare find, but it is definitely worth tasting. As David Embury put it in his 1948 The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks, it is a deceptively simple cocktail that can “whet rather than dull the appetite”. It's light, aromatic, and makes a perfect autumn cocktail. Embury also included The Jack Rose in the same book as one of the six basic cocktails. Isn't history fun?

name: Pisco Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Campo de Encanto Piscos are right at home on this traditional egg white sour, and with the brand's wide variety of Piscos the flavor of your Pisco sour is limitless.  Each label can bring a new subtle nuance to this cocktail.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters as a replacement for the Angostura bitters in this cocktail.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled
champagne flute or cocktail glass. Top with bitters.
notes: Americans have a fear of egg whites in their cocktails. It's completely irrational, but we understand. The Pisco Sour is the perfect example of a cocktail that can be bolstered by the use of egg white. Without it, this cocktail is thin on the palate and almost astringent. With it, it's almost like key lime pie in drink form. Both Chile and Peru claim to have invented the Pisco Sour, though each has a slightly different variation. The Peruvian version is a bit more complex and has some added depth, so we'll stick with it. Many recipes actually call for Peruvian key lime juice, so if you're looking for a really authentic version, try to find some. Beware of recipes that call for lemon juice though, as this is likely a translation error from the Spanish word limón.

name: Artillery
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
A clean classic gin is needed for the Artillery cocktail. This sweet variation on the traditional gin martini highlights the herbal qualities of the sweet vermouth. Fleischmann's spicy aromas which are followed by crisp celery and pine, create a wonderfully aromatic, and flavorful cocktail.  

Instead of Angostura bitters, consider Peychaud’s Bitters - a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: We owe this classic southern cocktail to the Chatham Artillery, Georgia's oldest military unit. The fine folks of Savannah have been mixing up this potent potable since at least the late 1700s. Legend has it that sometime around 1791, George Washington came to visit the Chatham Artillery on short notice. In keeping with their southern hospitality, the artillery members and their wives threw together what they had on hand and created this punch, which they then served at a ball in the president's honor. The punch was a hit and became a southern tradition, often being mixed in horse buckets when served in larger quantities. Watch out for this one. Like many delicious cocktails, it's been known to sneak up on people.

name: Aviation
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Aviation calls for an assertive, traditional, but not overpowering gin to blend with aromatic flavors of the cremè de violette and maraschino. Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin has a traditional botanical blend of juniper, licorice, lemon, rose and cucumber, but its light body and smooth taste make it an exceptional choice for this bright, aromatic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cherry.
notes: The story of the Aviation cocktail is a bit of a Cinderella story. According to David Wondrich, it has been flying under the radar ever since it made its first appearance on a cocktail menu in 1911. Hugo Ensslin first published the recipe for this lovely little libation in his Recipes for Mixed Drinks in 1916, combining gin, lemon juice, maraschino and crème de violette liqueurs. Unfortunately maraschino and crème de violette weren't exactly commonplace on most bar shelves at the time, so the Aviation had a shaky takeoff. Eventually, crème de violette disappeared entirely from the American market, resulting in a mouth-puckering variation of the original recipe. When it finally reappeared some 40 years later, the Aviation was revived. Crème de violette adds a delicate floral note, which balances the tartness of the healthy dose of citrus and gin.

name: Bee's Knees
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The bright lemon, floral rose petal and juniper berry botanicals in the Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin pair perfectly with the lemon and honey in the Bee's Knees cocktail creating a beautifully aromatic, subtly sweet gin cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled champagne coupe.
notes: Get a wiggle on and head on down to the gin mill if this sounds like your kind of cocktail. First recorded in 1934 by William Boothby, this particular brand of giggle water is sure to please even the toughest of crowds and quench the most insatiable of thirsts. One of the niftiest things about summer is high-quality local honey, and the Bee's Knees is the perfect way to take advantage. If you're open to experimentation, try using different types of honey from different places. This can have a profound effect on the taste of this cocktail even for those who don't boast a well-trained palate. All in all, this stuff is the cat's meow.

name: Clover Club
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This fruity version of a gin sour, will be showcased best with the spicy, juniper botanicals of Fleischmann's gin. It's bright citrus notes will enhance the lemon and raspberry portions of the cocktail giving you a perfect balance of sweet and tart.
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled red wine
glass.
notes: The Clover Club was an assemblage of bankers, lawyers, and other prominent male professionals who met at the Bellevue-Stratford hotel in Philadelphia beginning in the 1880s and continuing on until the First World War. A veritable boys club, if you will. Like so many organizations of its kind, the Clover Club eventually disbanded, but it's members left behind this little gem for us to remember them by. Many people shy away from egg white these days, but in truth, it lends little to no flavor to drinks. Egg whites are merely used to add body and texture to cocktails. In this one, raspberry remains the dominant flavor but by no means overpowers. Some people like to garnish the Clover Club with a mint leave. Technically that's a Clover Leaf—but we'll let it slide. And gentlemen, this drink may be pink, but remember where it came from.

name: Corpse Reviver No. 2
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The corpse reviver is all about balancing the bright citrus of the lemon and triple sec, and the herbal notes of the absinthe. The spicy coriander and pine of Fleischmann's Gin along with its citrus and herbal botanicals create a perfect bridge between the other ingredients, finding the balance which is key in the Corpse Reviver No.2
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The concept of “hair of the dog” has long been a source of debate amongst social drinkers. Science doesn't seem to have much to say on the matter, but bar-goers certainly do. In the early 20th century, bartenders swore by it so firmly that they created a whole arsenal of morning-after cocktails that they swore would get you back on your feet after an overly indulgent night out. Unfortunately, not many of these corpse revivers, as they were called, are still popular today. The Corpse Reviver #2 is the exception. This light, fragrant cocktail that is sure to refresh. It is also a great way to introduce people to gin and even absinthe since neither of them overpowers the other ingredients when this drink made properly. Snake oil or not, the Corpse Reviver #2 will not disappoint.

name: Damn-The-Weather Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin and its spicy botanicals give a layer of interest and depth to this fruit forward cocktail, while it's bright citrus aromas add balance and finish the cocktail crisp.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: No one likes being cooped up in the house during a snowstorm—or a polar vortex, as the weathermen seem to be calling it these days. That is unless you happen to have all the ingredients on hand to mix up one of these little wintry potions. First cited in the Savoy Cocktail Book in 1930, Damn the Weather is a typical Prohibition style cocktail, complementing gin with vermouth and citrus and rounding the whole thing off with a little bit of triple sec. Orange is the dominant flavor here, but the vermouth adds a certain earthy and herbal note which is accented by the gin. Like many cocktails from the Prohibition era, Damn the Weather contains more than just a little bit of alcohol, but that's alright. You weren't planning on going anywhere anyway, were you?

name: French "75"
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is a light, smooth, elegant gin with the traditional botanicals of a London Dry that perfect compliment the ingredients of a French 75. It's fresh aromatics of rose, juniper and cucumber and bright citrus make it an excellent gin choice for this bubbly classic.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into chilled champagne
flute and top with Champagne.
notes: The French 75 is a nod to the 75-millimeter M1897, which was the bread and butter of the French military during World War One. Widely regarded as the first modern piece of artillery, these canons could wreak havoc on a large scale in a very short period of time. The same can be said for this cocktail – especially some of the older recipes, which really pour on the gin. Some older versions also strain the base mixture into a Collins glass over cracked ice before adding the champagne, but opting for a flute with no ice will keep it from getting too watered down. This cocktail is a great blend of floral and herbaceous gin with bright, citrusy lemon, and stays pretty light on the palate. If you're looking for a richer, darker flavor profile, try using brandy or cognac in place of the gin.

name: Garnet
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Garnet cocktail is a rich fruit forward cocktail that calls for a gin that can stand up to the sweetness of the pomegranate juice. Fleischmann's gin has a traditional botanical blend of a London Dry style, which gives it the body to support and shine in this sweet cocktail. It's aromatics of spice and pine will also pair nicely with the grapefruit juice giving the cocktail depth and interest.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Flame orange
twist and add.
notes: Once upon a time, gin was the clear spirit of choice amongst Americans. After Prohibition, our palates drifted toward less complex flavor profiles, and vodka took the place of gin on the American market. In the decades that followed, gin-distillers would attempt to win back their clientele by replacing the heavy spice and juniper notes of classic, London-style dry gin with lighter citrusy notes that would have more appeal on this side of the Atlantic. The Garnet is a cocktail that really cashes in on this brighter flavor profile by pairing it with the tang of pomegranate and grapefruit. Since this cocktail plays on the absence of that Christmas tree spice so often attributed to gin, this cocktail is an excellent choice for anyone looking to cross over from vodka cocktails to something a little more complex.

name: Gershwin
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Gibson (Gin)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The fewer ingredients in a cocktail recipe the more important the quality and flavor of the ingredients become. Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin is an superior choice for the Gibson with its amazingly light and smooth taste. Handcrafted with great care to create a fresh aromatic flavor that compliments the vermouth and makes for delicious easy drinking.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add onion.
notes: When the drink is comprised of spirits alone, stir the ingredients so they remain clear and unclouded by shaking. A barspoon's curves help rotate the spoon during stirring, and the spoon bowl guides poured liqueurs into position for layered drinks.

name: Gimlet (Gin)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The rich lime flavor in the Gimlet is perfeclty matched with the bright lemon flavors of Fleischmann's gin, making it, along with its spicy juniper aromas a perfect choice of gin when making this classic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes:
If desired, substitute 1 oz. Rose's Sweetened Lime Juice for the fresh lime juice and
simple syrup.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:

name: Gin Buck
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The spicy herbal aromas of Fleischmann's Gin along with its sweet lemon flavors are showcased perfectly with the addition of refreshingly spicy ginger ale, making in an excellent choice for the Gin Buck.
instructions:
Pour gin and lemon juice into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Fill
with ginger ale and stir.
notes: The buck is yet another category of drinks lost to the ages. When a base spirit is mixed with ginger ale and citrus, the result is a Buck. Sounds simple, doesn't it? That's because it is. Like many simpler recipes, this one can be easily played with to cater to different tastes. Different base spirits can be substituted to yield different kinds of Bucks, a dash of your favorite liqueur can be added for some extra zing, or ginger beer can be used in place of ginger ale for hardcore ginger fans. Although this cocktail has disappeared from most contemporary cocktail menus, it is the predecessor to many of today's favorites, including the Moscow Mule, which introduced vodka to the American market in the middle of the 20th century. Sure, there are plenty of more complicated drinks out there, but like Leonardo Da Vinci said, simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.

name: Gin Gin Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The spicy ginger flavor and bright mint aromatics are the true stars of the Gin Gin Mule. Fleischmann's Gin, with its spicy, pine aromatics and crisp citrus flavor perfectly showcase those ingredients, creating a refreshingly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle mint with syrup and lime juice in mixing glass. Add gin and
ice and shake well. Strain into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with
ginger beer.
notes: The Gin Gin Mule, like most cocktails, is a variation on a variation. Created by Pegu Club owner Audrey Saunders, this cocktail is about as refreshing as it gets and, honestly, just plain delicious. Ginger and whiskey have long been a popular combination in cocktail recipes, but gin makes for better summertime drinking. Gin's botanicals are a perfect compliment to ginger's spicy bite, and mint exponentially increases this drink's cooling power. The trickiest part to making a great Gin Gin Mule is finding the right kind of ginger beer—and no, ginger ale won't do. If you're using a sweeter ginger beer, you might want to cut back on the simple syrup, but the most important factor is the spice. Spicier ginger beer will help all the other flavors pop against each other. Think of it as an air-conditioned Fourth of July fireworks display for your taste buds.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The candied lemon and herbal juniper aromas enhance the sweet refreshing flavors of the pineapple juice in the Harlem Cocktail, while the interestingly fruity and peppery finish cut the sugar and highlight the maraschino liqueur, making a balanced cocktail.

notes: The Harlem cocktail is a bit of an enigma. It is clearly one of New York's neighborhood keepsakes, as it bears the name of one of its five boroughs—much like the Manhattan. Unfortunately, little is known about its history though. Speculation has linked the Harlem to a few different cocktails, but no one really knows for sure where it comes from. It is almost reminiscent of a pre-Prohibition style cocktail, except that it calls for pineapple instead of citrus. In any case, the Harlem has an extraordinary flavor profile. Gin lends its herbs and botanicals, maraschino imparts its red-fruity goodness, and pineapple tops it all off with just a kiss of tropical flavor. If you're looking to break out of the ordinary, the Harlem is definitely for you.

name: Income Tax Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
The Income Tax cocktail calls for a London Dry gin to add aromatics and botanicals to the citrus sweetened gin cocktail. Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is a great choice, with its citrus forward flavor, but bright aromatics of juniper, cucumber, and rose to tie in the vermouth and produce a balanced cocktail.

Consider Peychaud’s Bitters in place of Angostura bitters in this cocktail. Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Income taxes—the thought alone is reason enough for a cocktail. Whether you're celebrating a hefty return, agonizing over what you owe, or an accountant who's just glad tax season is finally over, this is a great cocktail to take the edge off everyone's least favorite time of year. The Income Tax Cocktail dates back to sometime in the 1920s, when gin, vermouth, and orange juice were the skeleton of many a recipe. The addition of bitters is thought by many to be a nod to the bitterness of giving away a portion of one's hard-earned money to the government. Otherwise, rather befittingly, the history of this cocktail is largely no-nonsense. In any case, this is a drink that goes down well year-round.

name: Juniper Breeze No. 1
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin is an excellent choice for the Juniper Breeze No. 1. Its candied lemon and sweet juniper aromas enhance the tart fruit flavors, while its spicy peppery finish cut the rich sweetness of the elderflower cordial, creating a balanced cocktail.
instructions: Roll with ice in shaker. Pour into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.
notes: Imagine a perfect summer's day. Maybe you're sitting in a porch swing, maybe you're lying on a beach under an umbrella. A light afternoon breeze flutters gently by. You take a deep breath and bask in the glory of it all, and then you think to yourself, “I could really use a cocktail.” This is exactly what you need. The combination of gin and elderflower makes the Juniper Breeze #1 the perfect cocktail for lazy summer afternoons. It was created by one Ms. Julie Reiner, who has become somewhat of a fixture in the New York cocktail scene over the past 15 years. She has worked with a number of New York's finest establishments and is a co-owner of the Flatiron Lounge, where she says that this drink is very popular with her guests.

name: Last Word
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Last Word cocktail is a Prohibition era cocktail, complex, herbal, and tangy. Fleischmann's gin is a great choice of gin with it's interesting botanicals, rich in coriander, pine, and spice. These flavors pair nicely with the extremely herbal Green Chartreuse, creating a beautifully green, surprisingly balanced, classic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: A cocktail with a simple recipe, yet such a complex array of flavors is bound to win any argument. The Last Word was originally created at the Detroit Athletic Club sometime in the 1920s. Many people attribute this cocktail's name to Frank Fogarty, a popular vaudevillian monologist who brought it to New York, where Ted Saucier discovered it and published it in his cocktail book Bottoms Up! in 1951. After World War Two, the Last Word fell into obscurity until it was revived by Murray Stenson in 2004. Stenson, who was looking for a new cocktail to serve in the Zig Zag Café in Seattle, achieved great success with his findings. The Last Word went on to inspire several well-known spin-off cocktails and spread to bars around the world. Its vivid color and flavor profile are certainly hard to beat.

name: Martini (Traditional 2-To-1)
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist
or olive.
notes: Dry, dirty, up, on the rocks, with a twist, shaken—not stirred. The possibilities for specifications on a Martini are endless and often intimidating. The Martini is timeless. It's chic and sophisticated. Cocktail fads come and go, but the Martini has proven resilient, which is perhaps one of the reasons it stands above other cocktails. There are countless myths and legends recounting the alleged creation of this cocktail and each is as unlikely as the next when compared with history. Similar “Martini” recipes have cropped up throughout time all over the country, each bearing a unique twist in its ingredients or proportions. Often they share similar but not identical nomenclature—Martini, Martinez, Martine, Martigny, just to name a few. The truth is that the origins of this cocktail are likely to remain shrouded in mystery. But perhaps that's for the best. After all, solving the enigma breaks the legend.

name: Melon Stand
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This muddled watermelon cocktail is best showcased with a bright, citrus forward, dry gin to pair with the sweet watermelon and tart lemon juice. This cocktail can be manipulated to be more herbal with the use of an intensely botanical gin, but Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin is a great start for a well balanced, refreshing summer cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle melon chunks in mixing glass. Add remaining ingredients.
Shake with ice and strain into Collins glass filled with crushed ice. Garnish with watermelon.
notes: Nothing says summer quite like melon. From cantaloupe to honeydew to watermelon, there is just something about biting into a sweet slice of the stuff that will melt you like the summer sun. So what better way to celebrate summer than with a Melon Stand? It's the perfect cocktail to sip on the back porch on a hot day. And if you like Melon Balls, but want to try something a little more sophisticated, this is a great place to start. Melon imparts its sweet juicy flavor, but Aperol helps cut the sugariness, and gin provides that herbaceous backdrop that no other spirit can. The Melon Stand is perfect as a pre-cookout apéritif and is a great way to add a little flavor to your Fourth of July party.

name: Mercy, Mercy
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

muddle. Add gin and shake with ice. Strain into chilled cocktail
glass.

name: Monarch

remaining ingredients and ice. Shake and double-strain into chilled
cocktail glass. Add grapefruit twist.

name: The Moneypenny
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Moneypenny's fresh grapefruit juice is best paired with a bright citrus forward London Dry gin with fresh herbal aromatics. Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin with its notes of cucumber and rose, paired with a light body make it an excellent choice for the Moneypenny cocktail.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Shake remaining
ingredients with ice and strain into glass. Add grapefruit twist.
notes: Background information on the Moneypenny cocktail is even more elusive than background information on Miss Moneypenny herself. It's creation remains an enigma. Miss Moneypenny, a 007 character, is the secretary of M, the head of MI6 throughout much of the James Bond saga. She shares a very flirtatious relationship with Mr. Bond, but she never pursues him as she is too much of a lady. This is a tart cocktail, to say the least. The combination of grapefruit and lemon yields a rather acidic mixture, while gin and Lillet Blanc add drier floral notes. The raw sugar rim pulls everything together and saves the day. To put it into Bond terms, this cocktail is “shocking—positively shocking.”

name: Monkey Gland
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin's bright citrus aromas enhance the bitter orange of the Campari, while its rich herbal botanicals bond perfectly with the herbal qualities of the sweet vermouth, producing a bittersweet classic Italian cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange
twist.
notes: Appreciating the name of this cocktail takes a bit of a dark sense of humor. It is credited to Harry MacElhone, who owned the famous Harry's New York Bar in Paris. MacElhone named this drink for medical experiments carried out by a Russian doctor named Serge Voronoff. It seems that Voronoff, who was seeking a medical method of rejuvenation performed several experiments in which he grafted tissue from the naughty bits of monkeys onto humans. Whether or not his work was successful, this cocktail is certain to revitalize. The use of real grenadine will really pop against the backdrop created by the orange juice, and will help highlight the sweeter notes of the gin. If you're up for a bit of experimentation yourself, try adding a dash of absinthe. Even a few drops can add a whole new dimension to this cocktail.

name: Negroni
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin's bright citrus aromas enhance the bitter orange of the Campari, while its rich herbal botanicals body perfectly with the herbal qualities of the sweet vermouth, producing a bittersweet classic Italian cocktail.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass or ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Add orange twist.
notes: The story of the Negroni is a curious tale indeed. Sometime around 1920, an Italian Count named Camillo Negroni, who had recently returned from working as a rodeo cowboy in America—yes, a rodeo cowboy—went to a caffè. There, he ordered his favorite drink, an Americano, but requested that the bartender liven it up a bit by replacing the soda water with gin. The bartender also replaced the Americano's traditional lemon slice with an orange slice and named the drink after the Count.  For years, the Negroni was an Italian favorite, but it didn't leave home until well into the 21st century. A full-throttle cocktail renaissance had opened Americans back up to the taste of gin and bitters, so the moment was finally right for the Negroni to make it's way to America, where it has become a mainstay on cocktail menus everywhere.

name: Air Mail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso white rum's distinct sugar cane flavor, and light sweet body are perfect pairings for the honey syrup and dry champagne in the Air Mail cocktail.
instructions: Shake rum, lime juice, and syrup with ice. Strain into chilled champagne flute. Top with Champagne.
notes: Back in the mid-1900s, airmail was a common method for sending packages and letters, and was without a doubt the fastest way to get something from point A to point B. This cocktail derives its name from that very same idea—it's one of the quickest ways to get from A to B. The origins of the Air Mail are somewhat unclear. The recipe was first published in Esquire's Handbook for Hosts in 1949, but no one is quite sure exactly where it came from. Widely regarded as one of the better champagne cocktails, this fizzy concoction looks like liquid gold poured over ice and tastes like a Caribbean beach vacation in a glass. Email might have replaced airmail, but there's no substitute for this citrusy delight.

name: Blue Hawaiian
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Though a supporting ingredient in this rum based cocktail, the Blue Curacao is the true star in this tiki cocktail invented at the Hilton Hawaiian. Mr. Boston's Blue Curacao with it's sweet orange taste and electric blue color are perfect for this creamy tropical drink.
instructions:

speed. Pour into chilled highball glass. Garnish with pineapple and
cherry.
notes: Blue drinks have long been a source of controversy in the bar community. Most of them take their color from blue Curaçao, which is actually an orange liqueur that has been dyed with blue food coloring. The Dutch brought blue Curaçao to the European market sometime in the 19th century along with an entire spectrum of colored liqueurs. These brightly colored concoctions quickly made their way across the Atlantic and rose in popularity until Prohibition stamped them out in the US. It wasn't until 1957 that blue drinks made their way back into American pop culture, when Harry Yee created the Blue Hawaiian at the Hilton Hawaii Village in Waikiki. You can think of the Blue Hawaiian as the Piña Colada's flashier cousin. If you're in need of a little taste of a tropical getaway, this may be just the tonic you're looking for.

name: Caipirinha
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: With Cachaca 51's Subtle grassy notes, your caipirinha will always turn out more balanced than if you had used a bolder more distinct cachaca, Cachaca 51 is the best choice for those who are just experimenting with this style of sugar cane spirit.
instructions:
Muddle lime and syrup in old-fashioned glass. Add cachaça and stir.
Fill with ice and stir again.
notes: Over the past few years, the Caipirinha has taken the world by storm. It was named the official drink of Brazil in 2003 by then President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, more commonly known to his constituency as “Lula”. Once Lula had given the Caipirinha official status, bars all over the globe began churning them out. The name essentially means “little peasant”, as it is thought to have been created in the small town of Piracicaba. Like many other cocktails, this one is believed to have medicinal origins. It seems to have appeared sometime in the early 20th century to fight off the Spanish flu, and originally included garlic and honey in the recipe. Those ingredients were eventually removed and replaced with sugar and ice. Though it might not be the most effective medical treatment around these days, a couple of these are sure to improve your Samba steps.

name: Pegu Club
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Fleischmann's Gin is an excellent choice for the Pegu Club, with its bright lemon and spicy juniper aromas that pair perfectly with the orange curacao to create a elegant and refreshing classic cocktail.

Consider Peychaud’s Bitters an excellent replacement for Angostura bitters in this cocktail. The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The Pegu Club cocktail originated the Pegu Club in Rangoon, the capital of Myanmar or Burma, which was formerly part of the British Empire. The Pegu Club, named for the nearby Pegu River, made its way around the world with Brits and foreigners alike in the early 20th century. No one is certain who created it or when it was invented, but it must have been before 1927, as that was the year of publication of Harry MacElhone's Barflies and Cocktails, which was the first book to make mention of the Pegu Club. From there it became a mainstay in bar culture and a clear cultural reference.

name: Pink Lady
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin is a great choice for the Pink Lady with its bright candied lemon and spicy juniper aromas, that perfectly pair with the rich sweetness of the grenadine
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled red wine
glass.
notes: The Pink Lady, like many pink drinks, has been the object of sexism for many decades. This cocktail was already being served prior to the Prohibition era, but rose to prominence during those dark days when alcohol was a crime in America due to a need to mask the unpleasant flavors of bathtub gin and the like. After Prohibition, the Pink Lady was heaped in with all the other “girly drinks” and fell out of favor with male cocktail critics. At one point, it even ended up on Esquire's list of the ten worst cocktails. The truth is that this cocktail is no sweeter than most others and actually has a pretty complex flavor profile due in part to applejack and real grenadine. We think it's time to give the Pink Lady another chance. After all, sexism is so 20th century.

name: Cuba Libre
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Cuba Libre is a simple, refreshing cocktail with big flavor. Using a rum with a powerful cane sugar flavor gives this highball body, and sweetness. Calypso White Rum has a light body to keep the cocktail refreshing, but a dominant cane sugar flavor to give it a rich sweetness.
instructions:
Pour rum into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with cola and stir.
Squeeze lime into glass and add wedge.
notes: Even if you flunked Spanish 101, you probably already know that Cuba Libre means Free Cuba. This was both a battle cry during the Spanish-American War and a celebratory toast thereafter. Once Cuba had won its independence from Spain, Coca-Cola was sold freely on the Cuban market. It was a commonly mixed with Cuban rum—usually Bacardí—and a squeeze of lime. During the Second World War, American spirits were scarce outside the military, and the only substitute imported in substantial quantities was Caribbean rum. Due to the rationing of sugar, there were few products to mix with alcohol aside from Coca-Cola. Thus, the Cuba Libre surged in popularity. The harsh truth is that after Coca-Cola removed some of its more dubious components in 1903, we'll never know what the original Cuba Libre was like. But that shouldn't stop anyone from toasting “Por Cuba libre!”

name: Cuban Special
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
pineapple and cherry.

notes:
Created by ANDRES SANCHEZ, Philadelphia, PA.
You will find jars of wild hibiscus flowers in rose syrup at specialty
stores.

instructions:

name: Hemingway Daiquiri
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso White Rum in an excellent choice for the Hemingway Daiquiri with is light body and sweet cane sugar flavor. The sugar pairs nicely with the fruit juices, and allows the Maraschino to shine without drying out the cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled cocktail glass.
notes: There are many variations on the story of how the Hemingway Daiquiri came to be, but the general consensus is that the story begins with a bathroom break. While passing by El Floridita, a popular bar in Havana, Mr. Hemingway stopped off to answer nature's call and make use of the facilities. On the way out, he noticed the bartender preparing a large batch of Daiquiris and, not wanting to miss out on an opportunity, decided to try one. He told the bartender that he preferred his Daiquiris with no sugar and twice the normal dose of rum. The bartender made one as requested and named it after him. After the double dose of rum, the story gets a little fuzzy. Perhaps the bartender wasn't quite satisfied with the drink and decided to doctor it up with Maraschino and grapefruit juice. However it happened, this is an exceptional cocktail.

name: Passion Daiquiri
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Strawberry Daiquiri
instructions:
Muddle strawberries, lime juice, and syrup in mixing glass. Add rum
and schnapps. Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Daisy De Santiago

name: Dark'n Stormy
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: George Bowman's Small Batch Dark rum is an excellent choice for the Dark & Stormy. It's subtle aroma of coconut and vanilla are followed by the rich flavors of molasses, honey and brown sugar, that are a perfect pair for the spicy ginger beer and touch of lime.
instructions:
Pour ginger beer into an ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Float rum on
top.
notes: Only a handful of the cocktail recipes out there are trademarked. The Dark ‘n' Stormy is one of them. The Gosling family, who owns the rights to this recipe, began dabbling in rum in Bermuda in the 1860s. Their experimentation resulted in a distinctly rich, dark rum that they would eventually christen “Gosling's Black Seal”. Around the same time, British sailors began brewing beer on the island using ginger root, which was said to cure seasickness. Eventually, someone had the grand idea to mix the two together, and the Dark ‘n' Stormy was born. The name is said to come from a sailor who said that it was “the color of a cloud only a fool or a dead man would sail under.” Fool or not, you're bound to enjoy this cocktail. Just be sure to use Gosling's Black Seal, or you may get a call from Mr. Gosling himself.

name: El Presidente Cocktail No. 1
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Corpse Reviver is all about balancing the bright citrus of the lemon and triple sec, and the herbal notes of the absinthe. The spicy coriander and pine of Fleischmann's Gin along with its citrus and herbal botanicals create a perfect bridge between the other ingredients, finding the balance which is key in the Corpse Reviver No.2
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Like the Corpse Reviver, there are a few different variations on this cocktail, generally denoted by numbers. This particular recipe is essentially a softer, fruitier version of a Daiquiri. The combination of pineapple and rum is, as usual, reminiscent of a beach vacation and helps tone down the acidity of the lime. Grenadine imparts just enough sweetness and a tart pomegranate note for a bit of added depth. Be sure to use real grenadine syrup though, none of that chemical cherry nonsense. This cocktail is among Havana's many contributions to drink menus everywhere and is sure to refresh on even the most sweltering of summer days. Just be careful, these things go down like adult juice boxes.

name: The Pulitzer
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
mint.

name: Queen Elizabeth

name: Ramos Gin Fizz
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Ramos Gin Fizz is considered an "eye opener" cocktail, historically served to help those who consumed it wake up. It's tart, and creamy, and refreshing, and it calls for a bright, crisp gin. Sunset Hill's Small batch gin is an excellent choice, with its fresh botanical blend and light, smooth body.
instructions:
Shake all ingredients except soda water without ice well until foamy.
Add ice and shake well until chilled. Strain into chilled highball
glass. Top with soda water and stir.
notes: The Ramos Gin Fizz is one of New Orleans's most famous cocktails. When Henry C. Ramos invented this cocktail in 1888 at the Imperial Cabinet Saloon, his recipe called it to be shook for 12 minutes straight. To keep up with the demand, Mr. Ramos kept at least 20 people behind the bar making nothing but Ramos Gin Fizzes at all times. During certain festivals and holidays, he was known to have up to 32. After the end of Prohibition, this cocktail was revived, but the 12-minute shake time was left in the grave. It has a particularly frothy body as well as a remarkably sweet floral note imparted by the orange blossom water.

name: South-Side Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin freshness and bright aromatics pair harmoniously with the citrus and mint in the Southside cocktail. This summer cocktail is best supported by a light smooth gin with nuanced botanicals instead of a traditional London Dry.
instructions:
Muddle mint leaves gently in mixing glass. Add remaining
ingredients and shake with ice. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
Add the mint sprig.
notes: There are no less than three competing stories as to how the Southside cocktail came to be. Perhaps the most interesting of them hails from Chicago. In the 1920s, Chicago was a city under violent gang rule. Three bootleggers controlled the city, and a hard line was drawn between North and South Chicago. On the North Side, people drank gin and ginger ale, which, consequently, is called a North Side cocktail. South Side mobsters didn't have as much access to quality liquor and were forced to use stronger flavors to mask the taste of bad gin. The Southside cocktail is an example of one of the most successful recipes for doing just that. There are a couple of fun spins on this cocktail as well. Try adding soda water and serving it over ice for a Southside Fizz, or stick with the coupe and add a healthy dose of champagne for a Southside Royale.

name: Tom Collins
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The candied lemon and herbal juniper aromas enhance the bright refreshing flavors of the Tom Collins, while the fruity and peppery finish cut through the sugar, making a balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake gin, lemon juice, and syrup with ice and strain into Collins
glass. Add several ice cubes, fill with soda water, and stir. Garnish
with orange, lemon, and cherry. Serve with a straw.
notes: At one time, there were a great many Collins drinks out there, and many of them are still floating around today. You may have heard of a John Collins, a Charlie Collins, or others, but the Tom Collins is arguably the most famous. Perhaps this is due to America's past penchant for gin. Whatever the cause, the Tom Collins is one of those timeless mixtures of simple, pure ingredients, coming together to yield a delicious cocktail. According to legend, a waiter named John Collins at Limmer's Old House in London unwittingly lent his name to a popular drink made with Holland gin. From there, someone decided to experiment a little and switched the Holland gin out for Old Tom Gin. The name got changed accordingly, and several others followed suit with their own variations. Whatever the real story is, this is a summer drink that deserves a revival.

name: Tuxedo Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset HIll's citrus aromas brighten the herbal qualities of the Tuxedo cocktail, while it's floral botanicals bond brilliantly with the maraschino and vermouth, to create a clean, elegant classic.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add the cherry.
notes: The Tuxedo is certainly a blue-blood drink. It's part of a family of cocktails from the late 18th and early 19th centuries that Jerry Thomas might have referred to as “fancy martinis”—gin, vermouth, bitters, a dash of maraschino, and occasionally a little absinthe. Interestingly enough, in Daly's Bartenders' Encyclopedia from 1903, the Tuxedo recipe calls for Maple Gin, which, apparently, was dry gin sweetened with a drizzle of maple syrup. Apparently Daly was alone in his passion for maple gin, as it doesn't really seem to turn up anywhere else. Over the next several years, the Tuxedo continued to evolve with snapshots being taken from time to time in the form of written recipes. The more eccentric ones included sherry, which yielded an exceptionally dry, nutty cocktail. The maraschino and absinthe do a much better job of balancing the gin and vermouth, so we recommend sticking with them.

name: Vesper
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will enhance the bright citrus qualities of the gin and Lillet creating a delicately smooth cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice. Strain into chilled Champagne or cocktail glass. Add
lemon twist.
notes: Even if you haven't read a single James bond novel, you're bound to recognize this drink by name—though you may not know what's in it. Bond is infamous for his drinking habits, and indulges in everything from Dom Pérignon to Heineken. This tasty tipple is a sort of dressed up martini. When 007 specifies the contents of the Vesper in Casino Royale, he asks the bartender to use Kina Lillet, an apéritif wine from the Bordeaux region of France. Kina Lillet is no longer manufactured as the company altered its recipe in 1986 to create Lillet Blanc, a similar but less bitter version of their previous product. Many cocktail experts will suggest Cocchi Americano as the closest cousin to Kina Lillet, so use whichever you prefer. Why Mr. Bond prefers his Vesper shaken is a bit of a mystery. We recommend stirring to prevent clouding and over-dilution.

name: Diablo
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The vanilla and cinnamon flavors in Corazon Reposado were made to pair with ginger beer,  they will enhance the the ginger and fold the flavor of the creme de cassis into the drink.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled Collins
glass. Top with ginger ale. Garnish with lime.
notes: Many people never think about drinking tequila unless it's in a margarita or a shot glass. This drink is a perfect example of how the use of tequila can extend far beyond just that. The El Diablo is generally credited to the legendary Californian restaurateur Victor Bergeron, better known as “Trader Vic”, who seems to have concocted it sometime in the 1940s. The reasoning behind the name, which means the devil, is unclear. Perhaps it is a reference to its vivid red color or to the spicy notes imparted by the ginger beer. Crème de cassis, which is made from blackcurrants helps soften the ginger beer's bite and round out the flavor, and both harmonize well with the tequila. The balance of bright flavors in this drink makes it a great way to introduce someone to tequila without using sour mix or a salted rim.

name: El Niño
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The white pepper and fresh mint flavors of Monte Alban Silver are a excellent match for the fresh strawberry and lime in the El Nino. They will add depth of flavor, and a layer of interest to this refreshing fruit forward cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle lime, strawberry, and syrup in mixing glass. Add tequila and
rose water and ice. Shake briefly and strain into ice-filled oldfashioned
glass.
notes: There is an endless number of variations on the El Niño. So many that some of them don't even resemble each other in the slightest. This recipe, which is simply tequila, muddled fruit, and simple syrup is sure to make a sweet and tangy treat on a hot summer's day.  Always opt for high-quality ingredients with recipes this simple. When so few ingredients are involved, each one can have a dramatic impact on the flavor of the cocktail. If strawberries aren't in season, you can try playing around with different combinations of fruit. Just remember that citrus of some sort is important for balancing out the tequila. Happy muddling!

name: Mexican Firing Squad
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
The Mexican Firing Squad is a sweet and spicy cocktail with fresh fruit juice paired with spicy Angostura bitters. Monte Alban Silver is a great choice for this cocktail with its creamy honey and vanilla flavor, and spicy finish that are a perfect compliment to the flavors of the Mexican Firing Squad.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters in this cocktail, in lieu of Angostura bitters.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake and strain into ice-filled highball glass. Garnish with lime.
notes: This cocktail's name suggests that it might be deadly, but it's actually pretty light. It tastes similar to a Margarita, but it's not quite as boozy and gets a bit of added depth from the pomegranate molasses and bitters. Pomegranate molasses can be a bit tricky to find, but it's fairly easy to make at home. Just reduce some pomegranate juice with a bit of sugar and lemon juice, and you'll be all set. The Mexican Firing Squad's earliest mention is in Charles H. Baker Jr.'s The Gentleman's Companion, Volume II, published in 1946. In it, the vagabond bon vivant tells a story about wandering from bar to bar in Mexico City in 1937 and finally discovering this cocktail at a bar called La Cucaracha. Another great summer cocktail, the Mexican Firing Squad is perfect for warm weather and light enough that you can enjoy more than just one.

name: Paloma
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The subtle cooked agave qualities of Siete Leguas Blanco provides a wonderful foundation for this bright refreshing drink.
instructions:
Pour tequila into ice-filled Collins glass. Fill glass with soda and
stir briefly. Garnish with lime wedge.
notes: Now this is a drink that will wake up your taste buds. Grapefruit soda gives just enough sweetness while lime gives it a sour kick. Throw in a little salt and some tequila, and what more could you ask for? Soda also imparts a fizzy quality that makes any drink ten times more refreshing. If southern Mexico made champagne, it would probably taste something like this. In a pinch, grapefruit juice, soda water, and simple syrup can be substituted for grapefruit soda, but it will yield a heavier drink, so try to opt for the former. Some people like a salted rim; others prefer to throw a little salt straight into the drink. Either is fine, just don't omit it.

name: Hurricane
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Hurricane is a sweet and fruity cocktail that calls for quite a bit of rum. Using Calypso white rum, with its light, sweet sugary flavor will blend perfectly with the fruit flavors creating a balanced cocktail that is not over powered by the rum.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled hurricane glass. Garnish with orange and cherry.
notes: This French Quarter mainstay first made landfall sometime in the 1940s at Pat O'Brien's bar in New Orleans. Supposedly, the bar began as a speakeasy with the password “Storm's brewin'”—perhaps foretelling the creation of this cocktail. It would appear that Mr. O'Brien came up with the Hurricane in an effort to empty his stores of the large quantities of rum that his southern distributors required him to buy, hence the ample dosing of both light and dark rum. He poured his new concoction into glasses shaped like hurricane lamps and dubbed it the Hurricane. This cocktail is sticky-sweet and bursting with juicy flavors. Be careful though. It packs a category-five punch.

notes: The term “Knickerbocker” may be a bit unfamiliar to anyone who isn't from the Northeast. Historically speaking, New Yorkers come in 2 main varieties: Yankees and Knickerbockers. Yankees were the Puritan, Sabbath-keeping New Yorkers who liked to go to bed early and refrain from worldly pleasures. Knickerbockers were the antithesis of that. It's fitting really that there should be a cocktail named after them. The Knickerbocker Special is another great summer drink with a much more lush flavor profile than most other rum-based cocktails.  The grenadine provides a much darker taste and balances out the citrus, which tends to dominate in many drink recipes. If you really want to channel the Knickerbockers, try replacing the grenadine with raspberry syrup for an old school twist.

name: Bloody Mary
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: A clean, smooth, refreshing vodka is key in a Bloody Mary, which makes Platinum Vodka an excellent choice. Though many modern alterations on the recipe call for flavored vodkas, the original is perfectly represented with a bright, unflavored vodka, that enhances the fresh flavors of a well crafted Bloody Mary.
instructions: Roll with ice between both halves of Boston shaker. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish with lime and celery.
notes: All hail the Bloody Mary, queen of cocktails and hair of the dog incarnate, gracing brunch tables everywhere since, well…sometime in the early 1900s. Most everyone is familiar with at least some variation of this drink. The original version was said to be nothing but half vodka and half tomato juice. Luckily, people have been adding multitudes of spices, seasonings, and any other kind of flourish you can imagine for almost a century. More recent trends tend to revolve around the garnish. One can easily find a Bloody Mary with practically an entire salad and even meat served atop it for brunch on Sunday mornings. Many versions also make use of other base spirits such as gin, tequila, bourbon, or rye. Whatever your taste, this classic pick-me-up is sure to be easy to find in most any bar.

name: Mojito
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The mojito is a refreshingly sweet long cocktail that is often served with a sugar cane stick. Calypso white rum with its mixture of vanilla and spice and buttery vanilla and cane sugar finish make it an excellent rum choice for this cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle the limes, mint, and syrup in a Collins glass. Add the rum
with ice and stir well. Top with soda water. Garnish with mint.
notes: It's amazing how much of cocktail history takes place in Cuba. Then again, thanks to the dark days of Prohibition, American cocktail-enthusiasts have a very special relationship with Cuba. Not so long ago, Cuban rum was barely palatable. Even Cubans themselves had to find ways to mask its noxious funk in order to drink it. Farmers would take whatever they had on hand to make their rum go down more easily, and often what they had on hand were the ingredients to what we now know as the Mojito. As Prohibition spread across America, Havana became our favorite offshore bar. The drinks of the Cuban working class made their way to the capital and into the hands of thirsty American tourists who would later recreate them at home. It's a well-know fact that bartenders today have a love-hate relationship with the Mojito, but it remains, nevertheless, an undeniable classic.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso White Rum's sweet sugar cane flavor is a great compliment to the tart grapefruit and sweet orange marmalade, while its light body produces a delicately sweet and fresh cocktail.
instructions:

notes: If alcoholic beverages could be adorable, this one definitely would be. You may be familiar with Paddington Bear, a beloved character in English children's literature. Paddington Bear hails from Peru and loves orange marmalade and his red Wellington boots. When mixologist David Hamilton Boyd was given the challenge of creating a cocktail inspired by a children's book character, he turned to Paddington. The original recipe was served over crushed ice in a glasses slotted into a small, red Wellington boot and garnished with tiny orange marmalade sandwiches. To give it a little extra Paddington flare, he called it “Does a Bear Drink Rum in Peru? (Of Course He Does)”. For the sake of brevity, we'll just call it a Paddington. And don't worry. If you're all out of small, red Wellingtons and tiny marmalade sandwiches, you can strain it into a cocktail glass and serve it with a grapefruit twist.

name: X.Y.Z. Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This pleasantly dry cocktail requires a delicate rum with balanced sweetness, making Calypso White Rum and excellent choice from the X, Y, Z cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The XYZ cocktail is about as simple as it gets as far as cocktails go. This simplistic but refreshing recipe is an easy fix if your bar is running low, and you need to entertain. One of the great things about this cocktail is that, with an ingredient list this uncomplicated, you can really experiment with different styles of rum. The actual recipe calls for light rum, which will provide a light, clean flavor profile. But this drink is easy to experiment with. Using different styles of rum will showcase their various flavor profiles. If you're looking to play around with different types of rum but don't necessarily care for rum on its own, this cocktail could prove an invaluable tool for you.

name: Zombie
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: George Bowman Small Batch Dark Rum's subtle aroma of coconut and vanilla and rich flavors of molasses make it a great rum for the fruity, fun, and potent Zombie.
instructions:
Shake with ice and pour into chilled Collins glass. Garnish with
mint.
notes: There are two prevailing theories about the Zombie. The first is that it was named for the effect it could have on those who imbibed in its tiki goodness. The second is that it was a sort of tiki version of the corpse reviver, designed to bring back from the dead those who had over-indulged the night before. Either way, the fact is that the three different types of rum in this drink make it a little freaky to say the least. Like any good tiki drink, it's bursting with fruit flavor, but bitters and demerara lend this cocktail a much more complex flavor profile. All in all, this cocktail is absolutely delicious, but be careful—it's just as likely to cause a hangover as it is to cure one.

name: The Cinquecento
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Citronella Cooler

name: Cosmopolitan
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: With its rich buttery mellowness and cool crisp finish, Rain vodka is an excellent choice for the Cosmopolitan. The richness of this vodka balances the tart cranberry to create a wonderfully balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake well with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish
with lime.
notes: The legends surrounding the creation of the Cosmopolitan span multiple decades and numerous celebrities. It has generally been credited to one of two different bartenders, but a primitive version of this drink actually appeared on Ocean Spray cranberry juice labels around 1968. The Harpoon, as they called it, didn't call for Cointreau or triple sec though, and would have yielded a very bitter cocktail indeed. The Cosmo as we know it became popular in gay culture during the 70s and 80s and was picked up by a bartender at the Odeon in Manhattan in 1987. The Odeon was a well-known celebrity watering hole and was frequented by a number of stars. The Cosmo then made its way to the Rainbow Room, where Madonna famously posed with one. When HBO began featuring the cocktail on Sex and the City, mainstream culture latched on, and the rest, as they say, is history.

name: French Martini
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The French Martini is a delightfully sweet cocktail that when paired with a clean, refreshing vodka, can suit all palates. Rain vodka, with its smooth taste due to its addition of limestone water creates a wonderfully balanced fruity cocktail able to please introductory drinkers and aficionados alike.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: In all honesty, there isn't a lot about this cocktail that one might call “French”. The only truly French ingredient is Chambord, a black raspberry liqueur made in France's Loire Valley region. Between the Chambord and the Pineapple juice (which, as always, had better be fresh) this cocktail is unapologetically fruity. It makes a great drink for those who don't want to be overwhelmed by the taste their alcohol. For those who like a little more kick, some recipes call for gin instead of vodka. Either way, the key to making a great French Martini is to really shake the heck out of it. This will cause the pineapple juice to froth, which adds both to the presentation and the body of the drink. As the French would say, À la vôtre!

name: Georgia Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the refreshing qualities of a Georgia Mule.  While it's buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the lime, and sweetness of the muddled peaches to create a balanced summer cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle 1 peach slice in Collins glass. Add vodka, lemon juice, and
bitters, then stir. Fill with ice and ginger beer; stir again. Garnish
with peach slice.
notes: It seems like everyone has their own mule these days, and why shouldn't they? After all, what doesn't go well with vodka and citrus? The Moscow Mule was invented in the 1940s, and people have been putting their own spin on it ever since. If you've ever been to the great state of Georgia, you know that people there are proud as punch of their peaches. It's even the official state fruit. (With any luck, one day the Georgia Mule will be the official state cocktail.) Now, most Georgians will probably tell you that there's nothing better than a bowl of homemade peach ice cream on a humid summer day, but the Georgia Mule is just as tasty. Besides who ever heard of getting a buzz off a bowl of ice cream?

name: Harvey Wallbanger
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Platinum vodka's clean, refreshing flavor makes it an excellent choice for the Harvey Wallbanger. It's bright, crisp flavor enhances the sweet fruit, while its use of corn in the distillation pair perfectly with the Galliano for a smooth creamy finish.
instructions:
Stir vodka and orange juice in Collins glass. Add ice and stir again.
Float Galliano on top.
notes: The 70s were by no means the pinnacle of mixology. It was a decade riddled with sloppy drinks made with every shortcut bartenders could dream up. The Harvey Wallbanger, however, is an exception. It is one of the few recipes from that era that can stand up to the craft cocktail craze that has swept the nation over the past few years. Think of it as one of those Screwdrivers you used to drink back in college, but with a tasteful twist. Supposedly, the Harvey Wallbanger was named after a bar regular at Duke's Blackwatch Bar in Hollywood in 1952. Several years later, the company that imported Galliano discovered the drink and created a surfer-themed marketing campaign with the catchphrase, “Harvey Wallbanger's the name, and I can be made!” From there, the Harvey Wallbanger took off like a pair of speed skates at a roller disco.

name: Long Island Iced Tea
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka create a refreshing Long Island Iced Tea, while it's smooth, buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the tart lemon, providing a much better balanced drink
instructions:
Shake ingredients, except cola, with ice and pour with ice into
highball glass. Add cola for color. Add lemon.
notes: If you're looking for a strong drink, look no further. This powerful combination of five different spirits is sure to get you where you want to go. The interesting thing about the Long Island Iced Tea—or LIT, as it's commonly referred to—is that while it doesn't contain a single drop of actual tea, it certainly looks like tea and even tastes a bit like it. The LIT is treacherous though because it goes down so easily. Mention it at a party, and you're bound to end up listening to a string of anecdotes from every person there about that one time they drank Long Island Iced Teas on a night out. At any rate, this cocktail is sure to bring on the good times, whether you remember them or not. Beware, though, the hangover can be rough, so be sure to take preventative measures.

name: Madras
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the bright fruity flavors of the Madras while it's smooth, rich texture will cut the tart sweetness of the cranberry and orange juice, providing a wonderfully balanced drink
instructions:
Build in order given into ice-filled highball glass. Squeeze lime and

notes: The Madras is one of those nice refreshing cocktails that can really be drunk at any time of year—or day for that matter. It is uncomplicated and easy, accessible and straightforward. A perfect drink if you've had a long day at work and don't want to intellectually invest in appreciating a dauntingly complex cocktail. Plus it's largely fruit juice, so of course it's rich in vitamins and minerals—and sugar. The simplicity of the Madras makes it easy to whip up, even on a moment's notice. There is also plenty of room to play around with flavored vodkas and the like if you're feeling experimental.

name: Moscow Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the refreshing qualities of a Moscow Mule.  While it's buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the lime, providing a much better balanced drink.
instructions:
Pour vodka and lime juice into copper Moscow Mule mug or
standard beer mug. Add ice cubes and fill with ginger beer. Squeeze
lime wedge and add to glass.
notes: Despite what the flavored vodka craze might make you think, vodka is actually a fairly recent addition to the American liquor market. As recently as the 1930s, Americans hardly even touched the stuff. The Moscow Mule is the cocktail that single-handedly changed that fact forever. John G. Martin bought the rights to Smirnoff vodka for Heublein Spirits in the late 30s. He had a difficult time selling it though, and decided to partner up with Jack Morgan, owner of the British pub Cock ‘n' Bull in Los Angeles, who, incidentally, was having trouble selling off the large stock of ginger beer he had recently purchased. The two collaborated and came up with this simple, yet refreshing recipe, which ignited the vodka craze of the 50s and would later lead bartenders to create every kind of “Mule” imaginable.

name: The Blinker
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Thomas Handy Rye has such bold flavors of apricot, vanilla, and spice that pair perfectly with the raspberry syrup in the Blinker. It's dense aromas, and full body allows it to shine in this fruit forward sour.
instructions:

notes:
The original recipe, published in 1934, used grenadine, but the raspberry
syrup complements the grapefruit better. In this recipe, a thick ice-cream
