name: Blood and Sand
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Blood and Sand cocktail calls for a smooth scotch with delicate smokiness to pair with the fruit juice and cherry heering. Glenfarclas 10 year is a excellent choice, with it's light smokiness, and delicate aromas of dried fruit and spice, bonds brilliantly with the ingredients to create a balanced cocktail that non scotch drinkers can enjoy.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The Blood and Sand is one of only a few classic concoctions that use Scotch as a base. When made with a softer blend or single-malt, it's a great first step for Scotch skeptics. This cocktail takes its name from the 1922 Rudolph Valentino film by the same name; though some people also attribute the name to the colors of the ingredients. The Blood and Sand first appeared in print in 1930 in Harry Craddock's The Savoy Cocktail Book. The complex balance of smoky and fruity flavors at play in this drink is actually relatively flexible and can be adapted to the taste of the drinker by varying ingredients. For something a little bolder, try a smoky Islay Scotch instead. The flavors pair surprisingly well.

name: Bloody Scotsman

notes:
A busy barkeeper (or organized home bartender serving a big brunch)
will make up large batches of morning cocktails to get a head start on
serving. This great variation on the Bloody Mary theme uses Scotch to
give it a smoky note.
Makes 14 to 16 servings

name: Salty Dog
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Summer cocktails demand lighter spirits to brighten the fruit forward tipples, and in cocktails with only two ingredients, quality is key.  Sunset Hills Small Batch gin, with its smooth body and fresh taste creates a tasty premium cocktail.
instructions:
Rim highball glass with lemon and salt. Fill with ice. Add vodka and
grapefruit juice and stir.
notes: The Salty Dog is a slight variation on the Greyhound, which is simply gin or vodka with grapefruit juice. The flavor profile of gin tends to have much more depth than that of vodka, but hey, to each his or her own, right? All you need to do to transform your Greyhound into a Salty Dog is add a salted rim. Salt and gin might sound like an odd combination, but the salt really interacts with the grapefruit juice. If straight grapefruit is too sour for your taste, you can always add a dash of simple syrup to tone it down. Just be careful and don't overdo it, or you'll cancel out the salt.

name: Cotton Club Flip
instructions: Shake first four ingredients without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Top with bitters. Garnish with cotton candy.
notes:
Vanilla-Infused Bourbon:  Split 3 Tahitian vanilla beans lengthwise. Insert into 750-ml bottle
of bourbon. Close bottle and let stand at room temperature for 3 to 5 days. Remove vanilla beans. Store bourbon at room temperature for
up to 1 month.

Honey-Currant Syrup:   Bring 1 cup honey, ½ cup dried currants, and ¼ cup water to a simmer over medium heat in small saucepan, stirring to dissolve honey. Simmer over low heat for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Strain into jar, cover, and refrigerate for up to 3 weeks.

Buy some packaged cotton candy for this cocktail's garnish, or skip the candy and garnish with an edible flower.

name: White Russian
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The crisp, clean taste of Rain Vodka make it an excellent choice for the White Russian, as it blends well with the rich coffee liqueur and cuts the richness of the cream to create a well balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Pour vodka and coffee liqueur into ice-filled old-fashioned glass.
Fill with milk or half-and-half.
notes: When vodka first hit the American market around the middle of the 20th century, cocktail books often referred to vodka recipes as “Russians” because vodka was generally imported from—you guessed it—Russia. The predecessor to the White Russian was the Black Russian, which came along around 1949. The Black Russian is simply a White Russian without cream, hence the change of color. The White Russian was first documented in the mid 60s. From there it experienced a brief surge in popularity during the disco era, but fell out of favor until the release of the film The Big Lebowski in 1998, in which the character played by Jeff Bridges downs eight White Russians and drops a ninth one on the floor. White Russians can be drunk as a morning beverage if you're trying to cure a hangover, but be careful—drinking too many of them will only cause one.

name: Amaretto Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Amaretto Sours are a sweet nutty cocktail that calls for a full bodied spirit to pair with the bright citrus and sugar. di Amore Amaretto is an excellent choice with its rich body and caramel, almond flavors.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled sour glass. Garnish with orange.
notes: The history behind the Amaretto Sour is lost to the ages. Like many sweeter cocktails, this one often gets a bad rap, but fear not. Balancing out the sticky sweetness that the almond-flavored amaretto liqueur imparts to this drink is actually fairly simple. The first step is to ensure that the amaretto used is of good quality since it is the backbone of this cocktail's flavor. Second, use freshly squeezed, unsweetened juice to maximize the crisp, tart flavors needed to achieve a well-balanced drink. An egg white is always a welcome addition and will help to smooth out the boldness of these flavors as well. Fun fact: most amaretto contains no almonds at all, and actually gets its flavor from apricot pits—although for anyone who may be allergic, it's still a good idea to check the label.

name: Manhattan Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
cherry.
notes:
A hundred years after the Old-Fashioned, near the end of the 1800s, we find the Manhattan. In the second half of the 1800s cocktails began to really catch on, and bartenders were expanding both their repertoire of drinks and the palette of products at their disposal for making them.
Simplicity of design, however, was still very much at the core of all
drinks. The Manhattan appears to have come onto the scene about 1882, at which time it was mentioned that a cocktail made from just whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters was coming into vogue. It went by not only "Manhattan", but also "Turf Club Cocktail" and "Jockey Club Cocktail". The "Manhattan" moniker almost certainly comes from the Manhattan
Club of New York, with the other clubs eager to have their names
attached to the drink as well.

name: Mint Julep
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: No drink out there says southern culture quite like the mint julep.  This very old very traditional concoction, dates back to before The Kentucky Derby where it's the official drink.  Being such an old potable, W L Weller with it's long history as a proper Kentucky Bourbon, is a perfect fit.  The wheated recipe bring a wonderful mellow flavor to the drink, and as it melts, the drink transforms into something reminiscent of mint sweet tea.
instructions: Pour syrup into silver julep cup, silver mug, or Collins glass. Fill with shaved or crushed ice and add bourbon. Stir until glass is heavily frosted, adding more ice if necessary. (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) Garnish with mint so that the tops are about 2 inches above rim of glass. Use short straws so that it will be necessary to bury nose in mint, which is intended for scent rather than taste.
notes: The Mint Julep has been the official drink of the Kentucky Derby for almost a century now, and the fastest two minutes in sports just wouldn't feel right without a frosted silver cup in one hand. The origins of this drink predate the Derby by several centuries though. Like many of its cousins, the Julep was originally drunk for medicinal purposes. The name comes from the Arabic word julab and the Persian word gulab, which both translate to “rosewater”. In the early days of America, people made juleps with a number of spirits including rum and brandy, but history seems to suggest that the original julep was actually made with cognac. At the time, bourbon was reserved mostly for poor southerners who couldn't afford fine liquor. My how the proverbial tables have turned. Next time you're in bourbon country, be sure to try one of these classic southern libations.

name: Pimm's Cup
instructions:
Pour Pimm's into ice-filled Collins glass. Top with chilled ginger
ale. Garnish with cucumbers and/or lemon.
notes: The Pimm's Cup is an interesting link between the cities of London and New Orleans. Many New Orleanians seem to believe that the Pimm's Cup is native to their city, but it was actually brought there by the Napoleon House, a restaurant in the French Quarter. When the Napoleon House began serving Pimm's Cups, it was in an effort to prevent their clientele from completely inebriating themselves in the sweltering Louisiana summer heat. The Pimm's Cup originated in London though, where it is still drunk by the gallon in the summer. Pubs sell them by the pitcher, and at Wimbledon, over 40,000 pints of the stuff are sold within just two weeks. No one is quite sure how this cocktail made it across the Atlantic or which city drinks more of it. Whatever the case may be, the Pimm's Cup is just one more thing London and New Orleans have in common.

name: New York Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Because Buffalo Trace has large depth of flavor it is truly a go to whiskey for cocktails, but is exceptional in a New York Sour.  The soft dark fruit qualities in Buffalo Trace, bond brilliantly with the addition of port found in this cocktail, thus creating a superbly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled oldfashioned
glass. Float red wine on top. Garnish with lemon and
cherry.
notes: The New York Sour has gone by many names. Most people believe that it actually originated in Chicago, where it was called a Continental Sour, then made its way south, where it was called a Southern Whiskey Sour, before finally making its way up the East Coast into New York. Whatever you call it, it's an absolutely delicious—not to mention gorgeous—drink. If you can make a whiskey sour, you've already got the bulk of the technique needed for this tasty tipple. You can omit the egg if you like, but doing so will reduce the body and texture of the drink. Floating the red wine is simple enough. All you need is the back of a spoon and a steady pour. This drink is sure to impress whiskey and wine-lovers alike. Plus layering drinks is an impressive party trick.

name: Between-The-Sheets
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso white rum, when used in the Between the Sheets cocktail gives depth and sweetness to the cognac with its distinct cane sugar flavor. It's natural sweetness helps to tie the triple sec, tart lemon, and rich cognac together to create a smooth, well balanced cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled shot glass.
notes: Now here's a cocktail that will make you blush. Or at least it will make your cheeks turn red. As David Wondrich puts it, the Between the Sheets dates back to Prohibition, a time when America's moral fiber wasn't what it should've been—but than again, neither was its liquor supply. There are many provocative theories about the origins of this cocktail, but most people agree that it was first created sometime in the 1930s at Harry's New York Bar in Paris. Others say it traces back to the Berkeley Hotel in London. The truth is, as with many popular drinks, no one is really sure. A word of caution: though delicious, this cocktail is not to be taken lightly. Too many of these will have you reaching for the aspirin tomorrow morning.

name: Old-Fashioned Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Blanton's Bourbon with its dry vanilla notes and hints of nutmeg, is an excellent choice for the Old Fashioned. The old fashioned and its ingredients are made to highlight the base spirit so using Blanton's, a premium spirit will give you the highest quality cocktail.
instructions: Pour whiskey, syrup, and bitters into cracked ice-filled old-fashioned glass and stir. Garnish with orange and cherry.
notes: Some people say that history is a matter of perspective. The history of the Old Fashioned is precisely that. “Old Fashioned” is thought by many to have originally been applicable to any drink. It would have been like ordering a cocktail “the old-fashioned way”, which probably varied about as much as house rules in a game of Monopoly. In any case, the cocktail we now know as the Old Fashioned is said to have originated at the Pendennis Club in Louisville, Kentucky. Mixing drinks in the heart of bourbon country, it seems likely that the bartender would have used bourbon, but the Old Fashioned is also commonly made with rye whiskey for a drier and lighter cocktail. Several recipes call for muddled fruit and soda water, and there's nothing wrong with that per se. We prefer the more basic method though, as it really brings the whiskey to the foreground.

name: Charlie Chaplin
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Charlie Chaplin is a simple stirred cocktail that requires a premium bourbon with a flavorful body and smooth finish. Elmer T Lee Bourbon's rich flavor or vanilla and leather find a wonderful balance with the sherry and amaro, creating a complex, multilayered cocktail that still highlights the bourbon.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cordial glass.
notes: Charlie Chaplin, undoubtedly one of the most beloved figures in cinematic history and a jack-of-all-trades of the industry, was active in film for over 75 years. The Charlie Chaplin was created when its namesake was at the pinnacle of his career. First recorded in Albert Stevens Crockett's The Old Waldorf-Astoria Bar Book in 1935, this cocktail was served in the original Waldorf-Astoria hotel in New York City up until the 1920s. Due to the tremendous technological advancements of the early 20th century, the Waldorf-Astoria quickly grew outdated and its wealthy clientele drifted elsewhere. Consequently, it was sold and demolished in 1929 to make way for the Empire State Building. The current Waldorf-Astoria was opened in 1931, but the Charlie Chaplin never seemed to make it back onto the cocktail menu. This bittersweet, fruity mixture is sure to satisfy any sweet tooth and pairs great with salty bar snacks.

name: Melon Ball
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Mr. Boston Melon liqueur is a excellent choice for this fruity melon cocktail with its vibrant green color and sweet honeydew flavor, that are perfectly balanced by the vodka and tart orange juice to create a delicious cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cordial glass.
notes: Perhaps you've heard of a place called Studio 54. In case you haven't, here's a little background. Studio 54 was arguably the most famous nightclub in the world from 1977 to 1979. Located in Manhattan, this venue was a magnet for celebrities. Actors, artists, fashion designers, musicians; Studio 54 probably served at least one drink to nearly every famous name of the era that you can think of. And a good number of those drinks were likely Melon Balls. This cocktail packs quite a punch when it comes to flavor. Many recipes call for orange instead of pineapple juice, but the pineapple really highlights the bright, sweet flavor of the melon. The recipe can also be easily adapted to pitchers if you're hosting guests and drinks particularly well on the patio in summer. If you have a melon baller, try scooping out balls of honeydew and freezing them for ice.

name: Chi Chi
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The freshness and bright aromatics of Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin pair harmoniously with the citrus and mint in the Southside cocktail. This summer cocktail is best supported by a light smooth gin with nuanced botanicals instead of a traditional London Dry.
instructions:
Process ingredients with 1 cup crushed ice in blender until smooth.
Pour into red-wine glass. Garnish with pineapple and cherry.
notes: Think of the Chi-Chi as the Piña Colada's drier cousin. Pineapple and coconut lend a similar flavor profile to that of the Piña Colada, while the use of vodka instead of rum cuts back on the sugar. A good way to dip your toes in the water for those who aren't necessarily huge tiki fans, and a great alternative for anyone who gets a stomach ache after too many sugary drinks. This drink is generally credited to Donn Beach, or as most people knew him, “Don the Beachcomber”, who founded several tiki bars and restaurant and influenced the tiki fad a great deal in the 40s and 50s. For a truly authentic version, don't hold back on the garnishes. If you're feeling extra festive, you might even try serving your Chi-Chis in hollowed out pineapples. Although, glasses work just as well.

name: Vieux Carre
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
This New Orleans cocktail is fun, potent, and complex which makes Sazerac rye, with its romas of clove, vanilla, and anise, combined with its subtle notes of candies spices and citrus an excellent choice for the Vieux Carre.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters as a replacement for the Angostura bitters in this cocktail.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Pour into ice-filled old-fashioned glass and stir.
notes: The Vieux Carré is a slow-sipper. It's not a drink that you try to down in two minutes. No, this is a drink that needs to be relished, savored—a cocktail that almost slows down the passage of time. The name of this drink comes from a French nickname for the French Quarter in New Orleans meaning “old square”. It was invented at the city's famed Carousel Bar, and like the Big Easy itself, blends together diverse elements with strong characters to create something great. The use of Bénédictine and two different types of bitters lends this cocktail a multi-dimensional flavor that is fantastic in its complexity. If you're in New Orleans, be sure to stop by the birthplace of the Vieux Carré to enjoy one on the revolving Carousel Bar.

name: Walters
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Ward Eight
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sazerac Rye is the perfect choice for the Ward Eight. as it is full of body and spice to cut through the sweetness of the fruit juice, but also has a silky buttery quality that allows for a well interesting and balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into red-wine glass filled with ice. Garnish
with orange, lemon, and cherry. Serve with straws.
notes: The Ward Eight was invented in 1898 by bartender Tom Hussion at the Locke-Ober Café in Boston. Many of his customers were members of a political club called the Hendrick's Club, run by one Martin Lomasney. Lomasney ran for public office that year in Boston's Eighth Ward—now Roxbury and the South End—and one of the club members asked Hussion to create a drink to toast his victory. Hussion obliged and whipped up this little concoction for his patrons. The funny thing is that Lomasney was actually a staunch prohibitionist and would later close the bar that had invented this cocktail in celebration of his victory.

name: Washington Apple

name: Whiskey Smash
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Because Buffalo Trace has large depth of flavor it is truly a go to whiskey for cocktails, but is excellent for a Whiskey Smash.  The citrus and honey qualities in Buffalo Trace, pair brilliantly with the freshly muddled mint, thus creating a superbly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle sugar with soda water and mint in old-fashioned glass. Add
whiskey and then ice cubes. Stir. Garnish with orange and cherry,
and add lemon twist.
notes: Every Smash is a Julep, but not every Julep is a Smash—sort of like that rule about squares and rectangles that you learned in geometry class. We'll spare you all the historical details about what distinguishes the two though. Truth be told, in some cases it's a question of presentation. Smashes, like Sours or Daisies, can be made with any kind of base spirit, but whiskey is generally preferred. This minty cooler makes a great daytime beverage, and is simple enough to whip up even if you've already had a couple. Historically, Smashes included fruit, and many bars will muddle lemon into theirs. This adds a nice citrusy bite to the drink, but also brings it closer to a minty whiskey sour. However you prefer yours, the Whiskey Smash is the perfect libation summer afternoon.

name: Whiskey Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: EH Taylor rye whiskey is a great choice for a whiskey sour because the sharp spice, and bright acidity allows it to blend perfectly with the fruit juice while maintaining its identity. Because EH Taylor uses all rye and no corn in its mash blend, it has a unique dried fruit and pepper taste that brings depth to a simple classic.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
lemon and cherry.
notes: The Sour, like the Gimlet, can be traced back to sailors who drank various spirits with citrus to prevent Scurvy. The practice was brought to land on both sides of the Atlantic, but on the American side, people often preferred native whiskeys to rum and other spirits. Jerry Thomas included a popular recipe in his 1862 book The Bartender's Guide and called it a Sour. Like Smashes and Flips, Sours can be made with any spirit, but whiskey is perhaps most common. Jerry Thomas's recipe did not include egg white, which is a common ingredient nowadays. The egg white was added later for froth and texture. Many recipes call for an optional egg white but don't require it. The truth is that egg doesn't really affect the taste of a drink, but rather the body. However you make it, the Whiskey Sour is a great afternoon or before-dinner drink.

name: Whiskey Squirt
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into chilled highball
glass. Add ice and fill with soda water. Garnish with pineapple and
strawberries.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Whiskey Swizzle
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Pour whiskey, lime juice, syrup, and bitters into Collins glass. Fill
glass with ice and stir. Add ice and fill with soda. With barspoon
between your palms, move hands back and forth and up and down to
quickly rotate and lift spoon, until glass is frosted.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Whispers-of-the-Frost Cocktail
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
orange and lemon.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Whoa, Nellie!
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add grapefruit
twist.

name: Woodward Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Woolworth
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Frozen Strawberry Dacquiri
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into white wine glass. Garnish with whole strawberry perched
on rim of glass.

name: Banana Frozen Daiquiri
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into champagne flute. Garnish with cherry.

name: Mint Frozen Daiquiri
instructions:
Process all ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until
smooth. Pour into old-fashioned glass.

name: Pineapple Frozen Daiquiri
instructions:
Process all ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until
smooth. Pour into champagne flute.

name: Frozen Fuzzy
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into champagne flute. Garnish with lime.

name: Frozen Margarita
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into cocktail glass. Garnish with lemon or lime.
notes:
Vary the flavor of your Frozen Margarita by substituting fruit schnapps
for the triple sec and adding 1/2 cup of the desired fruit. Depending on the
fruit's sweetness, you may need to add simple syrup. Try berries in
season, mango, or melon.

name: Frozen Matador
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into old-fashioned glass. Garnish with pineapple.

name: Fruity Smash
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into cocktail glass. Garnish with cherry.

name: Gaelic Coffee
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into Irish coffee glass. Top with whipped cream and drizzle

name: Georgio
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into hurricane glass. Top with whipped cream, sprinkle with a

name: Golden Cadillac
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This disco era cocktail is a sweet, and creamy after dinner treat. Mr. Boston's White Cream de Cacao is an excellent choice, with its rich chocolate flavor and notes of vanilla perfectly pairing with the sweet orange Galliano and cream.
instructions:
Combine with 1/2 cup crushed ice in blender on low speed for 10
seconds. Pour into chilled champagne flute.
notes: Grab your old letterman's jacket and head on down to Poor Red's BBQ in California gold country if you want to sample one of these creamy creations. After allegedly winning his bar in a game of dice, Poor Red started serving up some of the best barbecue El Dorado had ever tasted. Sometime in the early 50s, a couple came in and asked the bartender to mix up a new cocktail to celebrate their recent engagement. The bartender noticed that the couple had arrived in a brand new golden Cadillac and decided to make a drink to match it. This is the recipe he came up with. The Golden Cadillac became so popular that Galliano eventually gifted Poor Red's with their very own Golden Cadillac to display outside the restaurant. Pretty hip, huh?

name: Hummer

name: Americano
instructions: Pour vermouth and Campari into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with soda water and stir. Add lemon twist.
notes: Just like it's caffeinated cousin, the Caffè Americano, the Americano cocktail was born in Italy. Originally though, it was known as the Milano-Torino, as Campari came from Milan and Punt e Mes came from Turin. Legend has it that when Italian bar-goers noticed a surge of Americans imbibing this particular concoction, they dubbed in the Americano, and the name stuck. In Ian Fleming's Casino Royale series, the Americano is the first drink ordered by the infamous James Bond himself. Gaspare Campari, for whom Campari liqueur is named, first served it at his famous Caffè Campari in Milan in 1860. Like so many Italian cocktails, it is an impeccable balance of sweet and bitter enhanced by refreshing herbal notes. Perfect with antipasti or just as a before-dinner drink.

name: Andalusia
instructions: Stir well with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Apple-Cinnaom Sparkler
instructions:
Gently fold ingredients with ice in mixing glass. Strain into chilled
champagne flute. Top with extra splash of sparkling wine or
Champagne. Add apple.

name: Bella Rosa
instructions:
Shake first five ingredients with ice, shaking hard to break up
strawberry. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Top with

name: Bellini
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Mr. Boston Peach Schnapps is a great choice for a bellini. It's fresh peach flavor and richly sweet body make it an excellent alternative to peach puree for this bubbly celebration cocktail.
instructions:
Pour puree into chilled Champagne flute. Carefully fill glass with
prosecco (watch out for foaming).
notes: Simplicity. It's the mark of a true Bellini. Fresh white peach puree and crisp, fizzy Prosecco. Italian summers are heavily perfumed by the abundant number of peaches that grow throughout the country, and there is a long history there of marinating these succulent fruits in local wines. In 1948, Giuseppe Cipriani created the first Bellini at Harry's Bar in Venice in an attempt to transform his favorite fruit into a cocktail for his patrons. His invention was a huge success, but the Bellini remained a seasonal treat until a French entrepreneur devised a method of freezing the fresh peach puree so that Mr. Cipriani could serve them year-round. The name is said to be inspired by the colors used by Venetian painter Giovanni Bellini in many of his works. An excellent choice for brunch, but perfect for humid summer evenings spent outdoors.

name: Bishop
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into ice-filled
highball glass. Fill with wine, and stir well. Garnish with fruit.

name: Blackberry Fizz
instructions: Muddle blackberries, lemon juice, and syrup in mixing glass. Add Lillet, gin, and ice and shake. Strain into chilled champagne flute. Top with sparkling wine. Garnish with blackberry.

name: Boston Orange
instructions:
Fill 1-pt. beer mug or pilsner glass with ale, leaving room at the top
for the vodka. Pour in vodka. Garnish with orange.

name: Brazil Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Brooklyn Tai
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into 1-pt. beer mug.
Gently pour in beer. Garnish with mint and lime wheel.

name: Broken Spur Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Champagne Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Consider world-famous Peychaud’s Bitters instead of Angostura bitters in this cocktail. The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Place sugar and bitters in champagne flute and fill with Champagne.
Add lemon twist.
notes: For those of you who enjoy hosting guests, this cocktail might just be your new favorite. Champagne Cocktails are classy, simple, and definite crowd-pleasers. Perfect for a DIY cocktail station if you're throwing a party. Interestingly enough, in the first edition Jerry Thomas's How to Mix Drinks, published in 1862, the instructions call for all ingredients to be shaken, including the champagne. A later edition of the same book rectified the mistake and altered the instructions, but who knows how many champagne catastrophes occurred in the meantime? Other versions of this drink also include a healthy dose of brandy, but those tend to be a bit heavier on the palate. If you're looking for a little variation, take advantage of the plentiful selection of aromatic bitters at your local spirit shop.

name: Almond Tea Toddy
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Garnish with orange.

name: Cherry-Vanilla Sparkler
instructions:
Gently fold ingredients with ice in mixing glass. Strain into chilled
champagne flute. Top with extra splash of sparkling wine or
Champagne.

name: Amaretto Tea
instructions: Pour hot tea into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add amaretto, but do not stir. Top with whipped cream.

name: Chrysanthemum Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: American Grog
instructions: Put rum, lemon juice, and sugar cube in preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with hot water. Stir to dissolve sugar.
notes: Water, water everywhere, and not a drop to drink. Such has always been the obstacle on long sea voyages. Before ships had electricity and refrigeration—in other words, throughout most of history—sailors had to find ways to stay hydrated whilst aboard their ships. Wine and beer quickly turned sour, and water went stale, grew algae, and became slimy. Sometime in the mid-1700s, Vice Admiral Edward Vernon issued an order for rum to be mixed with his ship's water supply to keep it from spoiling. His trick worked, and became standard practice amongst many sailors. The name “Grog” is a nod to Vice Admiral Vernon, who was nicknamed “Old Grog” because of a grogram jacket he often wore. Given his popularity amongst his crew, they dubbed the mixture “Grog” in his honor.

name: Aprihot
instructions:
Pour ingredients into preheated Irish coffee glass. Top with ground
cinnamon and garnish with citrus wheel.

name: Black Gold
instructions: Pour first four ingredients into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add coffee and schnapps and stir. Top with whipped cream and chocolate and add cinnamon stick.

name: Blue Blazer
instructions:
Warm two large, silver-plated mugs with handles with boiling water; pour out water. Put whiskey into one mug and fresh boiling water
into other mug. Ignite whiskey. While whiskey flames, pour into mug with boiling water. Repeat pouring from one mug into the other,
extending stream to a foot or so. If done well, this will have the appearance of a continuous stream of liquid fire. Sweeten with syrup. Pour into preheated Irish coffee glass and add lemon twist.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Claret Cobbler
instructions:
Pour soda water and syrup into ice-filled red-wine glass. Add wine
and stir. Garnish with fruit. Serve with straws.

name: Bourbon Spice Latte
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass. Float star anise on top.

name: Brandy Blazer
instructions:
Combine first two ingredients in preheated old-fashioned glass.
Light with a match and stir with barspoon for a few seconds. Pour
into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add orange twist.

name: Brandy Toddy (Hot)

Pour syrup into preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Fill with
boiling water. Add brandy and stir. Add lemon and sprinkle with

name: Cafe & Cachaca
instructions:
Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass. Top with nutmeg.

Coffee-Infused Cachaca
Combine 1/3 cup dark roast (Italian or French) coffee beans with 1
cup cachaca in a jar. Cover tightly and let stand at room
temperature for 5-7 days. Strain into bottle and store, refrigerated,
for up to 1 month.

It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

notes: Felix Kir, mayor of the French city of Dijon, popularized this drink in the years after World War II.

name: Frosted Apricot

name: The Gathering

name: Caffe Di Amaretto

instructions:

name: London Special
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Modern Lemonade

name: Pear Fizz
instructions:
Add lemon bitters to ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Pour in brandy

Garnish with pear slices.

name: Pear-Vanilla Sparklers

name: Red Diesel
instructions:
Pour cider and beer together into chilled beer mug and stir briefly.
Add crÃ¨me de cassis.
notes: A relative of the Shandy, with beer, cider, and a shot of currant liqueur to give the color that gives the drink its name.

name: Sangria
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy's smooth sweet aromatics along with rich fruit flavors make it a great choice for Sangria. It's notes of orange peel, apricots and vanilla enhance the fruit and the wine, while the tart alcohol leaves a crisp, balanced finish.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled red-wine glass. Garnish with
cinnamon and orange twist.
notes: The history of Sangria is fairly simple. As Rome conquered Europe, they continued expanding outward, eventually reaching the Iberian Peninsula, which is what we know as Spain and Portugal today. On their way, the Romans planted grapes to be able to make wine. At the time, water wasn't safe to drink, so it was a common practice to add alcohol, herbs, spices, and anything else that might kill of bacteria. The problem was that the table wine was so terrible that people would do anything to mask the flavor. This included adding fruit, juices, and even other types of alcohol to the wine in order to make it more palatable. Water may have since been made safe to drink, but the practice of making punch out of wine hasn't faded. Let's hope it never does.

name: Sangria Red
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled red-wine glass. Garnish with
orange.

name: Capriccio
instructions:
Rim preheated Irish coffee glass with orange and blend of sugar and
cinnamon. Pour next four ingredients into glass. Fill with coffee and
stir. Top with whipped cream, sliced almonds, and cherry.

name: Sangria White
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled white-wine glass. Garnish

instructions:

name: Shandy
instructions: Pour into chilled beer mug and stir briefly.
notes:
This mix of beer and lemonade is one of the most refreshing drinks ever

chilled champagne flute. Top with extra splash of sparkling wine or
Champagne. Garnish with strawberry.

name: El Tibio
instructions:
Combine rum, liqueur, and honey in preheated Irish coffee glass or
mug. Add tea and stir. Add bitters and cinnamon stick.

name: Tridentt
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Gin Toddy (Hot)
instructions:
Pour boiling water and sugar into preheated Irish coffee glass or
mug and stir to dissolve sugar. Add gin and stir again. Add lemon
and sprinkle with nutmeg.

name: Apple-Cinnamon Soda
instructions: Pour into ice-filled pilsner glass and stir briefly. Garnish with apple.

name: Handicapper's Choice
instructions:
Pour whiskey and amaretto into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill

name: Beach Blanket Bingo
instructions:
Pour juices into ice-filled highball glass. Top with soda water and

name: Blackberry Soda
instructions: Muddle blackberries with honey syrup and lemon juice in mixing glass. Add ice and shake. Strain into ice-filled pilsner glass. Top with ginger ale and stir briefly. Garnish with skewered blackberry and lemon.

name: Hot Apple Toddy

(Mixture does not need to boil.) Strain into preheated Irish coffee
glass or mug. Add Calvados and liqueur and stir. Garnish with
clove-studded orange.

name: Bubbletart
instructions:
Shake juices with ice and pour with ice into chilled highball glass.
Fill with soda water. Garnish with lime.

name: Bubbly Orangeade
instructions: Stir together in Collins glass and add ice. Garnish with orange.

name: Hot Brandy Alexander
instructions:
Pour ingredients into preheated Irish coffee glass. Top with cream
and chocolate.

name: Coffee Almond Float
instructions:
Combine milk, coffee, brown sugar, and almond extract in pitcher.
Stir well. Pour into ice-filled hurricane glasses. Top each with a
scoop of ice cream.
notes: Makes 4 to 6 servings

name: Hot Brick Toddy
instructions:
Put first three ingredients into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add
whiskey, fill with boiling water, and stir.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Hot Buttered Rum
instructions: Put syrup into preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Fill with boiling water. Add rum and butter and stir. Top with nutmeg.
notes:
Hot buttered rum is perhaps the ultimate chill-chaser. If you don't have Demerara syrup, dissolve 1 tsp. Demerara sugar (or light or dark brown sugar) in the boiling water.

Demerara Syrup: This syrup gives a richer, molasses-like sweetness and an earthy color to cocktails. Substitute 1 c. Demerara sugar for
the granulated sugar. Store in refrigerator for up to 2 months.

name: Hot Buttered Wine
instructions:
Pour wine and water into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add maple
syrup and butter and stir. Top with nutmeg.

name: Hot Cinnamon Roll
instructions:
Pour schnapps into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add cider and stir.
Top with whipped cream and add cinnamon stick.

name: Hot Gold
instructions:
Pour amaretto into preheated red-wine glass or Irish coffee glass.
Add orange juice and stir. Add cinnamon stick as stirrer.

name: Hot Kiss
instructions:
Pour whiskey and liqueurs into preheated Irish coffee glass. Add
coffee and stir. Top with whipped cream and garnish with a
chocolate-covered mint.

name: Indian Summer
instructions:
Rim preheated Irish coffee mug or glass with lemon and sugar. Add
schnapps and cider and stir. Add cinnamon stick, if using.

name: Irish Coffee
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Concannon Irish Whiskey with its light body and flavors of sweet honey, spice and oak make it an excellent foundation for an Irish Coffee.
instructions:
Stir sugar cubes and coffee in preheated Irish coffee glass to
dissolve sugar. Add whiskey. Float cream over back of barspoon to
fill glass.
notes: In comparison to Irish whiskey, the Irish Coffee is actually a fairly recent invention. In the 1940s, the most common air route between America and Europe included a stop in Foynes, an air base near Limerick, Ireland. Given the temperamental nature of the weather in western Ireland though, short layovers often turned into overnight stays. On a winter's night in 1942, a particularly nasty storm sent a plane back to Foynes for the night. The restaurant was notified to prepare food and drink as usual, but chef Joe Sheridan decided to prepare something special for the passengers aboard the plane. Legend has it that one American passenger asked if he was drinking Brazilian coffee. “No,” Joe answered, “that's Irish Coffee.” Eventually, the recipe was discovered by travel writer Stanton Delaplane, who took it back to San Francisco with him, where it became a signature cocktail at the Buena Vista Hotel.

name: Italian Coffee
instructions:
Pour amaretto into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and
stir. Top with ice cream and sprinkle with coriander.

name: Jamaica Coffee
instructions: Pour brandy, rum, and syrup into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and stir. Top with whipped cream and nutmeg.

name: Lumberjack
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass. Top with cinnamon

name: Mexican Coffee
instructions:
Pour coffee liqueur and tequila into preheated Irish coffee glass.
Fill with coffee and stir. Top with whipped cream.

name: Mexitaly Coffee
instructions:
Rim preheated Irish coffee glass with cherry juice and blend of
sugar and cinnamon. Pour liqueurs into glass. Fill with coffee and
stir. Top with whipped cream and chocolate.

name: Mulled Cabernet
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Heat ingredients together until hot but not boiling. Serve in
preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Add cinnamon stick.

name: Mulled Wine
instructions:
Heat wine and spices in metal latte jug with steamer spout of
espresso machine. (Or heat in a small saucepan over very low heat
just until steaming.) Pour into preheated Irish coffee glass or mug.
Add rum and honey and stir. Garnish with lemon.
notes: The steamer spout of an espresso machine does a great job of heating the wine with the spices. If you don't have one, be careful not to let the rum and spice come to a boil. Make it in quantity for a large group.

name: Coffee-Coal Cooler
instructions:
Combine coffee and maple syrup in pitcher. Slowly stir in cola. Pour
into ice-filled Collins glasses. Garnish with lemon.
notes: Makes 3 or 4 servings

name: Creamy Creamsicle
instructions:
Combine orange juice and ice cream in blender on low speed until
smooth. Pour into highball glass. Garnish with orange.

name: Peanut Butter Hot Chocolate
instructions:
Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Top with marshmallows
and cocoa.

name: Crow's Nest
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish
with lime.

name: Cucumber Peach Soda
instructions:
Muddle chopped cucumber, peach puree, lemon, and agave nectar in
mixing glass. Add ice and shake. Strain into ice-filled highball glass. Top with soda water and stir briefly. Garnish with cucumber slice.

name: Peanut Coffee
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass.

name: Razzmatazz
instructions:
Pour liqueurs into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and
stir. Top with whipped cream and berries.

name: Flamingo
instructions:
Shake juices with ice and strain into ice-filled highball glass. Top
with soda water and stir. Garnish with lime.

name: Ruedesheim Kaffe
instructions:
Place sugar cubes in preheated Irish coffee glass. Add brandy and
ignite. Let burn until it extinguishes itself (or cover tightly after 1 minute to extinguish). Fill with coffee and stir. Top with whipped cream and chocolate.

name: Fruit Smoothie
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender on low speed until smooth. Pour into
highball glass. Garnish with fruits.

name: Rum Toddy (Hot)
instructions: Stir sugar and water in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug to dissolve sugar. Add rum and stir. Add lemon and sprinkle with nutmeg.

name: Fuzzy Lemon Fizz
instructions:
Pour ingredients into ice-filled highball glass. Garnish with lemon
twist.

name: Ginger-Pomegranate Soda
instructions:
Pour into ice-filled pilsner glass and stir briefly. Add ginger and
lime.

name: Russian Coffee
instructions: Pour liqueurs and vodka into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and stir. Top with whipped cream.

name: Grapeberry
instructions:
Combine juices in large ice-filled red-wine glass. Garnish with lime
and serve with a short straw.

name: Iced Mocha
instructions:
Combine ingredients in pitcher and stir well. Pour into ice-filled
Collins glasses. Top with whipped cream and chocolate.
notes: Makes 3 to 4 servings

name: Innocent Passion
instructions:
Combine juices in ice-filled highball glass. Top with soda water and
stir. Garnish with cherry.

name: Lava Flow
instructions:
Process first four ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until
smooth. Put strawberries at the bottom of a parfait glass. Quickly
pour in blended mixture for a starburst effect.

name: Lemonade
instructions:
Stir lemon juice and syrup in Collins glass. Add ice, fill with water,
and stir again. Garnish with lemon and cherry, if using.

name: Lemonade (Raspberry)
instructions: Stir first three ingredients in Collins glass. Add ice, fill with water,and stir again.

name: Limeade
instructions: Stir juice and syrup in Collins glass. Add ice, fill with water, and stir again. Add lime and cherry, if using.

name: Lime Cola
instructions:
Add juice to ice-filled Collins glass. Fill with cola and stir. Add
lime.

name: Lime Cooler
instructions: Add juice to ice-filled Collins glass. Fill with tonic water and stir. Garnish with lime.

name: Little Engineer
instructions: Pour over ice in hurricane glass. Garnish with paper flag.

name: Snow Bunny
instructions:
Pour liqueur into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with hot
chocolate and stir. Add cinnamon stick

name: Spanish Coffee
instructions:
Pour brandy into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and
Pour brandy into preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with coffee and
stir. Top with whipped cream.

name: Spiced Apple Cider
instructions:
Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Garnish with clovestudded
orange.

name: Steaming Peach
instructions: Pour schnapps into preheated snifter. Add boiling water and stir. Float orange on top.

name: Orange & Tonics
instructions:
Pour juice into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with tonic water and
stir. Garnish with lime.

name: Orangeade
instructions: Stir juice and syrup in Collins glass. Add ice, fill with water, and stir again. Garnish with orange and cherry, if using.

name: Passion Fruit Spritzer
instructions:
Pour juice into champagne flute and fill with soda water. Garnish
with lime.

name: Tom and Jerry
instructions:
To make batter, beat egg whites and cream of tartar in medium bowl
to stiff peaks. Beat yolks in another medium bowl until slightly
thickened. Gradually beat in 1 cup of the sugar. Mix in rum,
cinnamon, cloves, and allspice. Mix in remaining 1 cup sugar. Fold
in whites. Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve, up to 2 days.
Makes 3½ c. batter, enough for about 28 drinks. For 1 serving, combine brandy and batter in preheated punch cup or
coffee mug. Fill with boiling water and stir well. Top with nutmeg.
notes: The Tom and Jerry is a warm and fuzzy Christmastime cocktail similar to eggnog. The main difference is that this drink is served hot. Although it has been largely forgotten in most parts of the country, the Tom and Jerry has been preserved in both Wisconsin and Minnesota, where, during the holiday season, regional markets even sell pre-made Tom and Jerry batter. The creator of this Yuletide brew was actually an Englishman by the name of Pierce Egan. He came up with the recipe and used it to promote a book he had authored and the subsequent stage play based on it. Contrary to what you might believe, the name is not a reference to MGM's animated cat-and-mouse duo, “Tom and Jerry”. Whether you're familiar with the creator or not, this cocktail is sure to warm you up on a cold winter's night and turn any day into a holiday.

name: Tom and Jerry (Creamy)
instructions:
To make batter, beat egg whites in large bowl to stiff peaks. Beat
yolks in medium bowl until thickened. Gradually beat in sugar until
very thick and pale yellow. Mix in brandy and rum. Fold in whites.
(If you have a Tom and Jerry serving bowl, transfer batter to bowl.)
Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve, up to 1 day.
For each serving, spoon batter into preheated punch cup or coffee
mug. Add milk to fill and stir. Top with nutmeg.
notes:
For 1 serving
1 oz. Tom and Jerry Batter
5 oz. hot milk, as needed
Garnish: Freshly grated nutmeg

name: Peach Melba
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender on low speed until smooth. Pour into
highball glass and garnish with raspberries.

name: Tom and Jerry for Two
instructions:
Beat egg white until soft peaks form. Beat egg yolk with sugar until
thick and pale yellow. Fold in white. Divide batter, brandy, and milk
between two preheated punch cups or coffee mugs and stir well. Top
with nutmeg.
notes:
Instead of the brandy, substitute light rum, or use a combination of
brandy and rum.

name: Pineapple Mint Soda
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into ice-filled
pilsner glass. Top with soda water and stir briefly. Garnish with
mint.

name: Pomegranate-Almond Soda
instructions: Pour into ice-filled pilsner glass and stir briefly. Add lime.

name: Whiskey Toddy (Hot)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Blanton's bourbons is full of complex aromas of vanilla, mint and molasses. It's smooth sweet to the taste of brown sugar and spice make it an excellent bourbon for the Hot Toddy.
instructions:
Stir sugar and water in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug to
dissolve sugar. Add whiskey and stir. Add lemon and sprinkle with
nutmeg.
notes: The Hot Toddy holds a place in history as a restorative draught intended to cure the common cold. Of course, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that there is any truth to this theory, and modern medicine would discourage such forms of self-medication. Doctors these days…ever the skeptics. There are two main theories about the origin of this cocktail's name. The more poetic of the two comes from Tod's Well, which was Edinburgh's water source in the 18th century. The more plausible one, however, comes from the name for an Indian drink made from fermented sap of different types of toddy palm trees. These drinks were absorbed into the British Empire and adapted to British tastes. As with all cocktails of this straightforward style, there are myriad variations to be made. To spice things up, try substituting tea or apple cider for the water.

name: Punchless Pina Colada
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into Collins glass. Garnish with pineapple and cherry.

name: Rumless Rickey
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Add juice, grenadine, and bitters to ice-filled old-fashioned glass.
Fill with soda water and stir. Garnish with lime.

name: Runners Mark
instructions:
Combine all ingredients in ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Stir.
Garnish with celery or scallion.

name: Ambassador's Morning Lift
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Shirley Temple
instructions:
Add grenadine to ice-filled Collins glass; top with ginger ale.
Garnish with orange and cherry.

name: Strawberry Wonderland
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into snifter. Top with whipped cream and garnish with
strawberry.

name: Apricot Brandy Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Summertime Breeze
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into Collins glasses. Garnish with pineapple and strawberries.
notes: Makes 2 servings

name: Baltimore Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Sunshine Splash
instructions: Stir first five ingredients in hurricane glass. Add ice, fill with lemonlime soda, and stir. Garnish with pineapple.

name: Tomato Cooler
instructions:
Combine juices in ice-filled highball glass. Fill with tonic water.
Garnish with lime, dill, and cucumber.

name: Brandy Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Unfuzzy Navel
instructions:
Shake with ice. Strain into chilled red-wine glass. Garnish with
orange.

name: Eggnog (Cooked)
instructions:
Heat half-and-half and sugar in medium saucepan over medium heat,
stirring to dissolve sugar. Whisk egg yolks in large heatproof bowl
until thickened; gradually whisk in hot mixture. Return to saucepan
and stir with wooden spoon over medium-low heat until custard
coats spoon and reads 185Â°F on instant-read thermometer. Strain
through wire sieve into preheated large punch bowl; let cool. Stir in
rum. Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at least 4 hours. Whip
cream to soft peaks and fold into custard. Serve in punch cups and
top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Virgin Mary
instructions:
Add ingredients to ice-filled large red-wine glass and stir. Garnish
with lime.

name: Christmas Yule Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian

name: Wavebender
instructions:
Shake juices and grenadine with ice and strain into ice-filled
highball glass. Fill with ginger ale and stir.

name: Yellow Jacket
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish
with lemon.

name: Egg Crusher
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into oversized snifter. Top with nutmeg.

name: Frosty Nog
instructions: Process eggnog, amaretto, and 1 cup crushed ice in blender on medium speed until smooth. Pour into hurricane glass. Top with almonds and nutmeg.

name: Golden Eggnog
instructions:
Beat egg white with 1/2 tsp. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat yolk well
with remaining 1/2 tsp. sugar until pale and thickened. Add white and
gently fold together. Add liqueur and milk and mix gently. Pour into
ice-filled cocktail glass. Top with nutmeg and gold leaf.
notes:
Your guests will feel very special when presented with gold-topped cups of nog. To transfer the edible gold (or silver) leaf to the drink, use the tip of a fine-tipped artist's brush to lift a large flake of the gold from its tissue. Touch the edge of the flake onto the surface of the eggnog and
remove the paintbrush without getting the bristles wet.

name: Golden Eggnog (Large Batch)
instructions:
Beat egg whites with 1 Tbs. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat yolks
well with remaining 1 Tbs. sugar until pale and thickened. Add whites and gently fold together. Add liqueur and milk and mix gently. Pour into ice-filled cocktail glasses. Top each with nutmeg and gold leaf.

name: Imperial Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg

name: Maple Eggnog
instructions:
Combine ingredients in large pitcher and chill. Stir before serving.
Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Nashville Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Nog De Cacao
instructions: Pour over ice in old-fashioned glass and stir.

name: Old-Fashioned Eggnog
instructions:
In a large bowl, beat eggs until pale and foamy. Add sugar and salt, beating until thickened. Stir in rum, half-and-half, and milk. Chill at
least 3 hours. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Port Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Rum Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Russian Nog
instructions: Pour into ice-filled old-fashioned glass and stir.

name: Sherry Eggnog
instructions: Combine in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Whiskey Eggnog
instructions: Combine in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.
notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: The World Bar Eggnog
instructions:
Beat egg white with 1 tsp. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat egg yolk
well until pale and thick. Add white and gently fold together. Beat cream, almond, and vanilla extracts with remaining 1 tsp. sugar until stiff. Add to egg mixture and gently fold together. Fold in rum. Pour into ice-filled punch cup or cocktail glass. Top with cinnamon
and nutmeg.

name: The World Bar Eggnog (Large Batch)
instructions:
Beat egg whites with 1/2 cup sugar until soft peaks form. Beat egg
yolks well until pale and thickened. Add whites and gently fold together. Beat cream, almond and vanilla extracts, and remaining  1/2 cup sugar until soft peaks form. Add to egg mixture and gradually
fold together. Fold in rum. Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at
least 4 hours or overnight. Pour into punch bowl and top with nutmeg and cinnamon. Serve, without ice, in punch cups or cocktail glasses.

name: Apricot Orange Fizz
instructions:
Combine first four ingredients in pitcher and stir. Pour into icefilled
Collins glasses, about 2/3 full. Top each with soda water and stir. Garnish with limes. Serve in punch cups.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Stir first six ingredients into large punch bowl. Add Champagne and soda water and stir. Add large block of ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve
in punch cups.

name: Boom Boom Punch
instructions: Stir first three ingredients in large punch bowl. Add Champagne and stir again. Add large block of ice.Garnish with bananas. Serve in punch cups.

name: Brandy Punch
instructions: Stir in large punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve in punch cups.

name: Brunch Punch
instructions: Combine in large punch bowl and stir well. Add large block of ice. Garnish with citrus. Serve in punch cups.

name: Cape Codder Punch
instructions: Stir in large punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Serve in punch cups.

name: Cardinal Punch
instructions: Stir in punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Serve in punch cups.

name: Champagne Cup
instructions:
Pour first four ingredients into pitcher and stir. Half-fill with ice
and top with Champagne. Garnish with fruit. Insert cucumber peels
inside pitcher and top with mint. Serve in red-wine glasses.

name: Champagne Punch
instructions:
Stir in large punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Garnish with fruit.
Serve in punch cups

name: Banana Punch
instructions:
Mix 1 1/2 quarts water and sugar in large bowl to dissolve. Add juices
and bananas. Pour into 4 (1-quart) freezer containers and freeze
overnight. About 1 hour before serving, unmold and transfer to large
punch bowl to melt slightly. Stir in club soda. Serve in punch cups.
notes: Makes 40 servings

name: Double Berry Punch
instructions:
Chill cranberry juice with ice block in punch bowl. Just before
serving, slowly pour in soda and stir gently. Add sherbet. Serve in
punch cups, adding sherbet and raspberries to each serving.
notes: Makes 25 to 30 servings

name: Funshine Fizz
instructions:
Combine first three ingredients in blender in batches, blending until
smooth. Pour into pitcher and stir in soda water. Serve in Collins
glasses.
notes: Makes 6 to 8 servings

name: Tropical Cream Punch
instructions:
Whisk condensed milk and juice concentrates in punch bowl. Add
club soda and stir gently. Add block of ice and garnish with orange.
Serve in punch cups.
notes: Makes 22 servings

name: Hot Apple Brandy
instructions:
Simmer all ingredients over low heat for 30 minutes. Serve warm in
snifters.
notes: Makes 8 servings

name: Champagne Sherbet Punch
instructions:
Stir pineapple and lemon juices and Champagne in punch bowl. Add
sherbet. Serve in punch cups, adding a portion of sherbet to each
glass.

name: Citrus-Beer Punch
instructions: Remove zest from 6 lemons with vegetable peeler and reserve. Juice lemons; you should have 2 cups Bring 2 cups water and sugar to a boil in large nonreactive saucepan. Add lemon zest and remove from heat. Cover and let stand 5 minutes. Add lemon juice and grapefruit juice. Strain into large pitcher, cover, and refrigerate until chilled. Just before serving, add beer. Serve in punch cups, garnished with lemon wheels.

name: Hot Burgundy Punch
instructions:
Bring sugar and 1 1/2 cups water to a boil in large nonreactive saucepan over medium heat, stirring to dissolve sugar. Add apple juice, lemon zest, cinnamon, allspice, and cloves, and bring to simmer. Cook over medium heat for 15 minutes. Strain into another saucepan and add wine. Simmer over low heat but do not boil. Serve
in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.
notes: Makes 8 to 10 servings

name: Hot Rummed Cider
instructions:
Bring cider and sugar to a boil in large saucepan. Reduce heat and
add butter. When butter is melted, add rum. Serve in punch cups,
with cinnamon sticks.
notes: Makes 8 servings

name: Smuggler's Brew
instructions:
Heat first five ingredients in large saucepan until boiling. Heat
brandy in small saucepan until barely warm and add to rum mixture.
Serve in punch cups.
notes: Makes 8 servings

name: Claret Cup
instructions:
Pour ingredients into large pitcher. Stir. Fill with ice. Garnish with
fruit. Insert cucumber peels inside pitcher and top with mint. Serve
in red-wine glasses.
CIDER PUNCH: Substitute apple cider for the red wine.
notes: Also known as a Loving Cup, make this with a full-bodied, fruity red wine.

name: Claret Punch
instructions:
Pour over large block of ice in punch bowl. Stir well. Serve in punch
cups.

name: Extra-Kick Punch
instructions:
Stir hot water and brown sugar in large heatproof bowl to dissolve
sugar; let cool. Stir in remaining ingredients. Cover and chill. Pour
over block of ice in punch bowl. Serve in punch cups.

name: Warm Winter Cider
instructions:
In large saucepan, bring cider and cinnamon to a full boil over
medium heat. Reduce heat and add rum, brandy, and schnapps,
stirring until heated through. Serve in punch cups garnished with
cinnamon sticks and apples.
notes: Makes 18 to 20 servings

name: Fish House Punch
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Meukow rich fruit and spice flavors make it a excellent choice of cognac for the classic Fish House Punch. It's sweet aromas and flavor pair nicely with the recipe, and hold up to the abundance of ingredients allowing its flavors to shine.
instructions:
Stir in punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve
in punch cups
notes: Philadelphia summers are hot. Air conditioning certainly helps, but in the middle of the 1700s, a century and a half before it was invented, alternative cooling methods had to be employed. Enter Fish House Punch. In 1732, Philadelphia saw the founding of the State in Schuylkill Fishing Corporation, a fishing club for some of its elite. They built a clubhouse on the edge the Schuylkill (pronounced “Skookul”) River and fiddled around with punch recipes until they settled on an official one. Apparently, these guys really knew what they were doing. The club is still functional, and their punch is still delicious. Like other punch recipes, this would've originally been mixed up in a substantial quantity in a punch bowl and served to a large group. This stuff is so tasty you might be inclined to drink the whole bowl yourself. Watch out though. This punch is mighty potent.

name: Kentucky Punch
instructions: Stir all ingredients except soda in large container and chill. Pour into punch bowl over large block of ice and stir in soda. Serve in punch cups.

name: White Wine Cup
instructions:
Pour ingredients into large pitcher. Stir. Fill with ice. Garnish with
fruit. Insert cucumber peels inside pitcher and top with mint. Serve
in white-wine glasses.
notes: Makes 6 servings

name: Whiskey Sour Punch
instructions:
Combine ingredients over block of ice in punch bowl. Stir gently.
Garnish with oranges. Serve in punch cups.
notes: Makes 32 servings

name: Mint Julep Punch
instructions: Cook mint jelly and 2 cups water in large nonreactive saucepan over low heat, stirring until jelly melts. Let cool. Stir in pineapple juice, bourbon, 2 cups cold water, and lime juice. Cover and chill. Pour over block of ice in punch bowl. Slowly pour in soda, stirring gently. Garnish with lime and mint. Serve in punch cups.

name: Rhine Wine Cup
instructions:
Pour ingredients into large pitcher. Stir. Fill with ice. Garnish with
fruit. Insert cucumber peels inside pitcher and top with mint. Serve
in white-wine glasses.

name: West Indian Punch
instructions:
Pour ingredients into large punch bowl. Stir. Add large ice block.
Garnish with bananas. Serve in punch cups.
notes: Makes 48 servings

name: Sangria Punch
instructions:
Pour wine, syrup, and 1/2 cup water into pitcher and stir. Add orange
and lime. Half-fill pitcher with ice. Add soda water and stir gently.
Add fruit. Serve in red-wine glasses, adding fruit to each glass.

name: Tequila Punch
instructions:
Pour first five ingredients into large punch bowl and stir. Add large
ice block and fruit. Serve in punch cups.

name: Appetizer No. 3 Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into 3 oz. cocktail glass.

name: Approve Cocktail
instructions: Stir well in ice and strain into 3 oz. Cocktail glass.

name: Absinthe Frappe
instructions: Shake up long enough until the outside of the shaker is thoroughly covered with ice. Strain into 4 oz cocktail glass.

name: Addington Highball
instructions: Stir well and strain into 7 oz. glass and fill with soda water. Squeeze orange peel on top.

name: Alfonso Cocktail
instructions: Stir slightly, fill up with Champagne. Use Champagne glass.

name: Apparent Cocktail
instructions: Shake well and strain into 3 oz. cocktail glass.

name: Appetizer Cocktail
instructions: Shake well and strain into 3 oz. cocktail glass.

name: Appetizer No. 1 Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into 3 oz. cocktail glass.

name: Appetizer No. 2 Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into 3 oz. cocktail glass.

name: Apple Toddy
instructions: Use Hot Whiskey glass. Fill with Boiling Water. Grate nutmeg on top.

name: Apricot Rickey
instructions: Take 1 Cube of Ice, Juice of 1/2 or whole Lime, 1 Drink of Old Mr. Boston Apricot Nectar. Fill up with Carbonated Water and serve with small bar spoon in glass. Use 8 oz. Highball glass. Leave lime in glass.

name: Atty Cocktail
instructions: Shake well in ice and strain into 3 oz. Cocktail glass.

name: Bebida Royal
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain. Serve in 8 oz. stem glass half filled with ice.

name: Big Bad Wolf Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into 4 oz. Cocktail glass.

name: Bitter Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into 3 oz. Cocktail glass.

name: Blenton
instructions: Stir well in cracked ice and strain into 3 oz. Cocktail glass. Add Cherry.

name: Blinker
instructions: Shake in ice and strain into 8 oz. stem glass. Serve with large piece of ice.
notes: According to David Embury in the 1930s, this drink was “one of a few cocktails using grapefruit juice. Not particularly good, but not too bad.” We respectfully disagree. This cocktail, first published in 1934 in Patrick Gavin Duffy's The Official Mixer's Manual, is a perfect balance of tart citrus and a sweet syrup, rounded out by a spicy rye. A great way to really savor the taste of the whiskey even if you're not in a neat or on-the-rocks kind of mood. The Blinker is an excellent choice for a winter cocktail, especially since everyone knows that grapefruit juice is good for fighting off a cold. If you're looking for variation, try substituting a quality raspberry syrup for the grenadine.

name: Planter's Punch
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into a large goblet. Add cube of ice and decorate with fruit.
notes: Planter's Punch has a definite Caribbean feel to it, but its origins are actually disputed. One story says that a Jamaican planter's wife came up the recipe as drink to cool off workers. Another story claims that it was invented at the Planter's Hotel in St. Louis. Either way, this cocktail was first mentioned in print in the New York Times in 1908. Like many other drinks, there are countless variations on Planter's Punch. Many recipes don't even specify what fruit juices are supposed to be used. If you play around with it a bit, you will find that, like most punches, it is a very versatile drink that can work with any number of different flavor combinations. Also in keeping with its punch status, this is a great party drink and is easy to make in large quantities.

name: Glogg
instructions: Pour the wine into a kettle. Insert cheesecloth bag containing remaining ingredients and boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour one 750-ml Brandy over sugar, making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted, replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot in punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

name: Wassail Bowl
instructions: Combine water and spices in a large saucepan and simmer for 10 minutes. Add sherry and ale and stir in sugar. Heat, but do not boil. Beat 12 egg yolks until they are pale and thick: fold in 12 stiffly beaten egg whites. Strain half the ale and sherry mixture over the eggs. Pour into a warmed punch bowl. Bring the remaining hot mixture to a boil and strain into punch bowl. Add brandy and apples.

name: Milk Punch
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into collins glass. Sprinkle nutmeg on top.
notes: Milk Punch is a famed cocktail throughout the South, especially at Christmas time. It's one of the few drinks that are sure to bring out that warm, cozy feeling even though they're best served chilled. This cocktail isn't just a source of Yuletide cheer though. New Orleanians often drink it for brunch year-round, and it can be particularly refreshing after the occasional indulgent evening. In Colonial America, milk and brandy were thought to have strong medicinal properties. This tasty elixir grew quickly in popularity, and eventually people started drinking it for pleasure rather than for health—and who can blame them? Milk punch is like homemade ice cream, but better. If you have the supplies, opt for freshly grated spices. You will taste the difference.

name: Coffee Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy with its sweet caramel and butterscotch aromatics, combined with its smooth body and light spice from the barrel, create an excellent pairing with the port wine used in the Coffee Cocktail #1.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into sour glass. Sprinkle nutmeg on top.
notes: Decaf drinkers, have no fear. You will find nary a drop of caffeine in this little delight. The Coffee Cocktail seems to have been given its name for two reasons. The first is its café color. The second seems to have something to do with people's penchant to replace after-dinner coffee with an after-dinner inebriant—not that we disapprove. This drink appears to trace all the way back to the 1887 edition of Jerry Thomas's The Bar-Tender's Guide. At a time when the word cocktail invariably indicated the use of bitters, this drink was a misnomer in more ways than one. Still, it grew in popularity and eventually became a classic. The Coffee Cocktail makes a superb after-dinner drink, but can also serve quite well as an apéritif. And for those with a caffeine aversion, it is, of course, caffeine-free.

name: Singapore Sling
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Singapore Sling is a fruity gin cocktail with a little spice found in the Angostura bitters and Benedictine. Fleischmann's gin, with its bright candied lemon flavor and spicy juniper aromas cut the sugary sweetness of the fruit juice, and enhance the interesting spice of the Benedictine, making it an excellent choice for the Singapore Sling.
instructions: Shake lemon, sugar, and gin with ice and strain into collins glass. Add ice cubes and fill with club soda. Float cherry-flavored brandy on top. Decorate with fruits in season and serve with straws.
notes: The Sling was a type of drink typically made with gin that was mixed with a bit of water, flavored, sweetened, and served cold. The Singapore Sling is a variation on this theme that was developed at the turn of the 20th century by Ngiam Tong Boon, a bartender at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore. If you visit the hotel today, you can actually see the safe where Boon stored his cocktail books. The Singapore Sling was taken off the hotel menu at one point and nearly forgotten. When the hotel wanted to revive it some time later, the bartenders had to rack their brains to remember the recipe. As is common with older cocktails, few people agree on how to make this one. Different recipes call for different fruit juices and even different liqueurs. Whatever your school of thought, this is a sweet, complex cocktail that you're sure to love.

name: Bijou Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Named after the French word for "jewel" this refreshingly herbal cocktail can be just that when Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is used. This drink requires a quality gin with citrus, and floral botanicals to brighten the cocktail, while also highlighting the interesting flavors of the Campari, and Chartreuse.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass. Add a cherry on top.
notes: One of the earliest known mentions of this late 19th century cocktail is in Harry Johnson's 1882 Bartender's Manual. Bijou is French for jewel and was supposedly named because the colors of the three ingredients—gin, vermouth, and Chartreuse—resembled diamonds, rubies, and emeralds. This drink is packed with big, bold flavors typical of the pre-Prohibition era, but eventually fell out of popularity as American palates drifted toward simpler flavors. The original recipe, which calls for equal parts of the three ingredients, is wildly herbaceous in the most delicious of ways. If it's a little over the top for you, just ask your bartender to please dial back the Chartreuse and vermouth. This will yield a drier, more approachable flavor profile. If you're making your own, remember that dilution is key with a cocktail of this strength.

name: Gimlet
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into cocktail glass.
notes: Medicine isn't nearly as much fun as it used to be. The Gimlet was actually invented by naval surgeons for the British Merchant Navy to help prevent sailors from getting scurvy. In the past, the British were often referred to as “Limeys” due to their penchant for sucking on limes for vitamin C. But when Navy doctors began noticing that sailors were throwing theirs out, they concocted this refreshing little tipple to better ensure the health of their patients. Apparently a spoonful of sugar—and a couple of ounces of gin—really does help the medicine go down. The recipe eventually made it back to the mainland and is still an anchor on cocktail lists to this day. As for scurvy, it hasn't posed a real health threat in quite some time, but hey, better safe than sorry.

name: Scotch Milk Punch
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into collins glass. Sprinkle with nutmeg.

name: Scotch Mist

name: Thistle Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass.

name: Purple Gecko

name: T.N.T. No. 2

name: Traffic Light Cooler
instructions: Into pilsner glass filled with ice cubes, first pour the melon liqueur, then the tequila, to create a green layer. Add sour mix. Slowly pour orange juice against side of glass to create the yellow layer. Add a few more ice cubes, if needed. Carefully float the sloe gin on top for the red layer. Garnish with a cherry and lemon and lime wheels. Stir just before drinking.

name: Wild Thing
instructions: Pour over ice into old-fashioned glass. Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: Blue Monday Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass.

name: Bull Frog
instructions: Pour over ice in collins glass and garnish with a slice of lime.

name: Cappucino Cocktail
instructions: Shake well with ice. Strain into cocktail glass.

name: Cosmopolitan Cocktail
instructions: In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients. Shake well and strain into a Martini glass. Garnish with lime wedge.

name: Jericho's Breeze

name: Seabreeze

notes: *Bourbon, Blended, Rye or Canadian.

name: Amore-Ade
